entry.title: This ancient port in England is having a 21st-century renaissance
entry.summary:
Hastings is popular in the spring and summer, when the sunlit sea is turquoise, the seafront rides are in full swing and the entire town heads out for Jack in the Green â€” a day of folk dancing, parades and merriment held on May Day. Tradition and innovation combine in this historic port town on the East Sussex coast in southern England.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Mention Hastings and people still refer to the battle of 1066, which is a shame given the town has changed so much â€” since the 11th century, certainly, but over the past decade, too. Like many British seaside resorts, Hastings and its neighbour, St Leonards-on-Sea, had their heyday in the Victorian era before falling into a period of decline. Their revivals in recent years haveâ€¦

entry.title: Can food bring people together? Stanley Tucci thinks so.
entry.summary: Stanley Tucci, host of the new series Tucci in Italy, ventures beyond Rome to Lazio's less-visited countryside to understand the relationship between the ancient metropolis and rural heartland. From a pine-needle pesto in Trentino-Aldo Adige to a Roman pizza in Lazio, the host of Tucci in Italy tells us about the dishes and people that define some of Italyâ€™s most distinct regions. Stanley Tucciâ€™s new series has been 20 years in the making â€” or at least, thatâ€™s how long itâ€™s been since the idea first struck him. His mission? To ignite curiosity, not only about Italy, but the ways in which we can explore the world through food.Â Tucci in Italy, which premieres May 18 on National Geographic, follows the acclaimed actor and author as he navigates the culinary traâ€¦

entry.title: A practical guide to exploring the Alps' classic highlights
entry.summary:
Roads in the Alps are generally well maintained and signposted, but youâ€™ll need to be a confident driver to tackle inclines and hairpin bends. These mountains have long been winter favourites, and theyâ€™re now becoming increasingly popular in the summer, too. Hereâ€™s what to keep in mind when planning a warm-weather visit.  
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Wild as they are, the Alps are brilliantly accessible in the warmer months, whether you want to devise your own multi-day, cross-country trip on the frequent, efficient trains, or hit the trail on a long-distance, hut-to-hut hike. For planning, booking and money-saving tips, try this handy guide.
Pack for the outdoors. Bring layers: a breathable fleece, loose walking trousers, hikâ€¦

entry.title: Listening to birds sing really does soothe your brain. Hereâ€™s why.
entry.summary: A European robin, Erithacus rubecula, sings in a tree in Norfolk, England. Studies have linked the sound of birdsong to reduced levels of depression and anxiety. Spending time in nature is important for your mental health. But studies show that even just listening to birds singing can ease symptoms of anxiety and depression. Each spring, as billions of birds head north during peak migration, their melodic songs become impossible to drown outâ€”not that you would want to. Their â€œdawn chorusâ€ signals that brighter, warmer days are finally here. Itâ€™s also a scientifically proven balm for your brain. Scientists know that nature is a salve for the soul. Getting outdoors keeps your body active. Spending time in the forest lowers your stress, heart rate, and blood pressure. Gaziâ€¦

entry.title: The real-life rise and fall of Griselda Blanco
entry.summary:
Griselda Blanco is suspected of being involved in 40 murders across the U.S., including all three of her husbands. At its height, her network was pushing $80 million a month in cocaine. How did a girl who grew up in poverty in Colombia become an international narcotics queenpin pushing $80 million a month in cocaine?
The Godmother. The Black Widow. Queenpin. Griselda Blancoâ€™s many aliases and nicknames speak to the notoriety she gained by heading a billion-dollar, blood-soaked drug empire that stretched from Colombia to the United States.
The subject of the Netflixâ€™s Emmy nominated seriesÂ Griselda, Blancoâ€™s life blurred the line between fact and fiction as she clawed her way to a position of powerÂ in a violent world. So, who was the real woman behind the myth?
Blanco waâ€¦

entry.title: Mark Synnott isn't afraid to be reckless
entry.summary: Writer Mark Synnottâ€™s ship, Polar Sun, navigates the northwest passage during a 2022 attempt to retrace the steps of famed British Explorer John Franklin. The adventurer and author of Into the Ice recounts his harrowing attempt to sail the Northwest Passage and why he always listens to his gut. In 2022, Mark Synnott set sail from his home in Maine to complete the Northwest Passage, the legendary route through the Arctic that connects the Atlantic and Pacific. Synnott wanted to retrace the path of an 1845 expedition led by British explorer Sir John Franklin, who was attempting to chart the sea route over North America and open a valuable trade avenue with East Asia. But along the way Franklinâ€™s two ships, Erebus and Terror, became trapped in the ice, stranding the expâ€¦

entry.title: A historic course correction: how the worldâ€™s shipping sector is setting sail for net zero
entry.summary: Long overlooked as a major contributor to global greenhouse gas emissions, the shipping industry is now at the forefront of a unique display of international cooperation. The shift signals that even the worldâ€™s largest transport sector can be steered toward climate accountability.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 8 million teens in world's wealthiest countries functionally illiterate: UNICEF
entry.summary: Children in many of the worldâ€™s wealthiest countries saw marked declines in their academic performance, mental wellbeing, and physical health as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a new report published by the UN Childrenâ€™s Fund (UNICEF) on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Funding cuts in Afghanistan mean â€˜lives lost and lives less livedâ€™
entry.summary: In a remote village clinic in the Bamyan Province in Afghanistan last week, a group of teenage girls were given potentially life-saving reproductive health advice, excited by the small kit of menstrual supplies they had been given.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Politically unacceptable, morally repugnantâ€™: UN chief calls for global ban on 'killer robots'
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres has once again called for a global ban on lethal autonomous weapon systems â€“ machines capable of taking human lives without human oversight â€“ describing them as â€œpolitically unacceptableâ€ and â€œmorally repugnant.â€

entry.title: UN aid office denounces attacks on Gaza hospital
entry.summary: The UN humanitarian affairs office, OCHA, underlined the need to protect civilians and healthcare facilities in the Gaza Strip in a renewed appeal on Wednesday.

entry.title: In Berlin, broad backing for UN peacekeeping as global threats mount
entry.summary: More than 130 countries and international partners threw their weight behind UN peacekeeping at a high-level ministerial summit in Berlin on Wednesday, pledging military, tech and political support.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: US-Houthi ceasefire â€˜a welcome opportunityâ€™ to advance peace efforts in Yemen
entry.summary: The ceasefire between the United States and Houthi rebels in Yemen provides an opportunity to revitalize the peace process in the Middle Eastern country, the UN Security Council heard on Wednesday.

entry.title: Passports Are Key to Uncovering Offshore Secrecy â€” We Use Machine Learning to Find Them Efficiently
entry.summary: Passports can help unlock secret ownership of offshore companies, but finding them is often challenging. At ICIJ, we decided to build a new detection tool to speed up this process.

entry.title: Video: How common are spiritual beliefs in the U.S.?

entry.title: How changing the way you breathe can improve your brain and body
entry.summary:
If youâ€™ve ever been told to â€œtake a deep breathâ€ during a stressful moment, know that this advice isnâ€™t merely a platitudeâ€”itâ€™s backed by science.
Research shows conscious breathing comes with a host of immediate and long-term benefits that include improved heart health, reduced anxiety, boosted mood, improved cognitive function, and better sleep quality.
â€œBreathwork is one of the simplest and profoundly effective tools we have for calming the nervous system and boosting physical and mental resilience,â€ says Guy Fincham, founder of the breathwork lab at Brighton & Sussex Medical School in England and co-author ofÂ breathwork research.Â â€œAnd yet, precisely because itâ€™s so accessible, its power is often underestimated.â€Â
Hereâ€™s why mindful inhaling and exhaling can be so good foâ€¦

entry.title: Dogs. Bedbugs. Corn. They all have this one thing in common.
entry.summary:
Scientists are trying to define the situationship between domestic animals and humans. Under a new definition, populations of dogs and bedbugs are in, while horses and pigs are out.  You might think you know which animals and plants are considered "domesticated" or â€œdomesticâ€ and which ones aren'tâ€”but a new definition has launched a big debate among scientists.
Your pet pug is without a doubt a domestic dog. A cow on a farm seems domestic, too. But what about an indoor/outdoor cat, that brings home unwelcome gifts? What about animals that live in our homes to our chagrin, like a rat or a bedbug?
Even among scientists, there is no universally agreed upon definition of what domestication looks like or what makes an animal â€œdomestic.â€ Elinor Karlsson and Kathryn Lord faced tâ€¦

entry.summary: This is a Pew Research Center analysis from the Pew-Knight Initiative, a research program funded jointly by The Pew Charitable Trusts and the John S. and James L. Knight Foundation. Find related reports online at https://www.pewresearch.org/pew-knight/. Research Kirsten Eddy, Senior ResearcherKaterina Eva Matsa, Director, News and Information ResearchMichael Lipka, Associate Director, News and Information ResearchNaomi [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: What Is News?
entry.summary: As people are exposed to more information from more sources than ever before, how they define and feel about â€œnewsâ€ has become less clear-cut. The post What Is News? appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: This Pew Research Center study uses a multimethod approach to understanding what â€œnewsâ€ means to Americans today. The project includes three different types of research methodologies: a qualitative online discussion board with 57 U.S. adults, a nationally representative survey of 9,482 U.S. adults conducted through Pew Research Centerâ€™s American Trends Panel (ATP), and on-the-record, in-depth [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Remember the Ice Bucket Challenge? Itâ€™s back.
entry.summary:
People participate in the "Ice Bucket Challenge" in Gloucester, MA during the last annual "Plunge 4 Pete" on Dec. 28, 2019, what would have been Pete Frates' 35th birthday. The fundraiser started in 2012 after Frates' diagnosis of ALS, and eventually helped popularize the Ice Bucket Challenge. The 2014 social media trend put the spotlight on unanswered questions and needed treatments for ALS. Will its return help? We asked the father of one of the original Ice Bucket Challenge founders.
More than a decade after the viral trend first got its start, thousands of people are dusting off their buckets and dumping ice water on their heads all over againâ€”but this time, for mental health.
The viral 2014 Ice Bucket Challenge raised $115 million in six weeks for what was, at the time, aâ€¦

entry.title: Why Panama City's appeal goes far beyond its namesake canal
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
At first glance, Panama City is all flashy skyline, its slew of sparkling high-rises towering above the waters of the bay like a cartoon vision of a futuristic metropolis. But the so-called â€˜Miami of Central Americaâ€™ has a hidden history â€” one that extends far beyond the canal that first put it on most travellersâ€™ mental map.
Panama is effectively a borderland between Central and South America, and its famous canal â€” built in the early 1900s â€” slices the country in two. This 51-mile waterway is a giant shortcut, connecting the Pacific and Atlantic oceans, sparing sea travellers an 8,000-mile voyage around the continentâ€™s southern tip. Each year, billions of dollarsâ€™ worth of cargo travel along it, and the comings aâ€¦

entry.title: Could beavers be the secret to the fight against wildfires?

author.name: Ben Goldfarb, Ronan Donovan, Kholood Eid

entry.title: The real science of brain rot
entry.summary:
In 2024, the Oxford University Press declared â€œbrain rotâ€ the word of the year. If Ohio is just a midwestern state to you and mewwing is something your cat does, you might not be as familiar with the term as those who have adopted the Gen Z and Alpha lexicons that popularized it. Still, youâ€™ve probably encountered its effects.
â€œBrain rotâ€ describes the supposed mental decline resulting from too much time spent in the chasms of the digital world reserved for trivial content. But, while endless hours scrolling on TikTok may prompt a headache, strained eyes, and the latest trending sound to loop in your head, â€œyour brain doesnâ€™t literally rot until after death,â€ says Andy McKenzie, a neuroscientist who studies functional brain preservation at the nonprofit Apex Neuroscience in Oregon. Anâ€¦

entry.title: Why there's a 10,000-person wait list to scavenge Londonâ€™s Thames
entry.summary:
ON A SUMMER DAY in central London, a 44-year-old woman named Lucy Peel descended a slippery stairway on the bank of the River Thames to crouch on her hands and knees over a particularly intriguing pile of mud. It was low tide, and the waters of the river had receded substantially. Ignoring the obvious tangles of trashâ€”plastic bags, vape pens, broken glassâ€”Peel painstakingly scanned the exposed riverbed until she spotted something nestled in the sand that could easily be mistaken for a leaf. After carefully prying it loose, she held up a wafer-thin ceramic shard and had a familiar feeling that she was holding a piece of ancient history.
Later, an archaeologist would confirm her suspicion: It was a fragment of Roman pottery. â€œEven though itâ€™s so fine, somehow itâ€™s still survived 2,000 yâ€¦

entry.title: UK's 'restaurants with rooms' offer a gourmet meal and a stay
entry.summary:
The Pig near Bath, in the Mendip Hills, has an extensive kitchen garden, with beds of greens, roots, herbs and fruit â€” as well as a mushroom-growing shed. These gourmet getaways offer world-class cuisine and stylish bedrooms, all under one roof.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
A meal at a great destination restaurant is the ideal activity around which to plan a trip â€” and what better way to extend the experience than by checking in overnight and doing it all again at breakfast the next day? Restaurants with rooms, where you come for the food and stay for the, well, stay can be found all over the UK. Here are some of our favourites, from a former pub in Yorkshire to a castle in the Scottish Highlands.
Having started life in the New â€¦

entry.title: â€˜Stop the 21st century atrocityâ€™ in Gaza, Fletcher urges UN Security Council
entry.summary: No aid has entered Gaza for more than 10 weeks and every single one of the 2.1 million people there faces famine conditions, the UN Emergency Relief Coordinator Tom Fletcher said on Tuesday in a briefing to the Security Council in New York.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Half of womenâ€™s organizations in crisis zones risk closure within six months
entry.summary: Womenâ€™s organisations operating in crisis settings are being pushed to the brink by widespread funding cuts. In a report published on Tuesday, UN Women â€“ the UN agency for gender equality â€“ warned that 47 per cent of these groups may be forced to close within the next six months.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: GAZA LIVE: 'Humanity, the law and reason must prevail' in Gaza, UN relief chief tells Security Council
entry.summary: The Security Council is meeting in New York to discuss the horror of Gaza, where humanitarians warn of â€œa critical risk of famineâ€ and aid shipments have been blocked by Israel for over 70 days. UN relief chief Tom Fletcher briefed the Security Council, asking ambassadors if they will act decisively "to prevent genocide" and ensure respect for international law. He also called on Hamas to release all hostages and stop putting civilians at risk. Follow live for key updates from UN Headquarters and reports from the region. App users can follow coverage here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: US deportations raise serious human rights concerns
entry.summary: The UN Human Rights High Commissioner Volker TÃ¼rk has voiced concern over the recent deportation of large numbers of non-nationals from the United States, particularly to third countries.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Number of internally displaced breaks new record with no let-up in conflicts, disasters
entry.summary: A record 83.4 million people have been forced from their homes around the world, fuelled by an increase in disasters and conflict, the UN migration agency, IOM, said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: As funding cuts bite, UN chief announces new dawn for peacekeeping
entry.summary: The future of peacekeeping took centre stage on Tuesday in Berlin as UN chief AntÃ³nio Guterres urged Member States to do more to support the global bodyâ€™s 'blue helmets' and stave off the worst impacts of deep funding cuts.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: 57 children reported dead from malnutrition, says WHO
entry.summary: In the aid desert of Gaza, malnourished children are dying while survivors can now expect a lifetime of dire health problems, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN aviation council finds Russia responsible for downing of Malaysian Airlines flight
entry.summary: A UN body has found that Russia was responsible for the 17 July 2014 downing of Malaysian Airlines flight MH17 over eastern Ukraine that killed all 298 people on board.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 2025 Global Shining Light Award Finalists: Small and Medium Outlets
entry.summary: Six intrepid investigative projects from small and medium news outlets have been selected by GIJN as finalists for the 2025 Global Shining Light Awards.

entry.title: Tariff timeline with China, so far
entry.summary: The U.S. and China put a semi-hold on tariffs for the next 90â€¦ Tags: China, New York Times, tariff

entry.title: English wine is on the rise. Here is where to experience it
entry.summary:
Domaine Evremond, established by Taittinger, produces Chardonnay, Pinot Noir and Pinot Meunier vines on its south-facing slopes in Kent. Savour the best of English wine with new festivals and vineyard experiences.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
There was a time, not so long ago really, when English oenophiles looking to set up shop had no choice but to relocate to the balmier climes of France or Italy. Not anymore. A changing climate, a culture of experimentation and greater awareness of which regions are best suited to grape growing have combined to make England one of Europeâ€™s most exciting viticultural destinations â€” and it shows. Across the country, youâ€™ll find tours and tastings that showcase some of Englandâ€™s best homegrown producers. â€¦

entry.title: Alcohol is killing more women than ever before
entry.summary:
Jasmine Charbonierâ€™s heavy drinking started in college. By her early 30s, she was downing up to eight tequila cocktails daily, several days each week. A few years ago she tried to quit and was surprised when she plummeted into withdrawal.
Research shows that while men are still more likely to die from an alcohol-related disease, the gap is narrowing. The most recent figures, published in 2024, found deaths in women have risen at a rate of 35 percent, while men increased just 27 percent.
(8 things we've learned about how alcohol harms the body.)
The rise in deaths results from an unfortunate gender equality: Women now raise their glass almost as frequently as men. A recent U.S. government survey found 45 percent of women drank in the prior month, compared to 50 percent of menâ€¦

entry.title: The secret program that brought Nazi scientists to the U.S.
entry.summary:
On July 20, 1969, a crew of American astronauts successfully landed on the moon for the first time. Though only three of them were in the spacecraft, thousands of people had contributed their brainpower to put the astronauts in flight.
Among the contributors: German scientists who had been members of the Nazi Party. The United States recruited them in the years after World War IIÂ under a federal program called Operation Paperclip.Â
The program remains a controversial chapter in American history, when U.S. officials incorporated former Nazis into American life and institutions. Hereâ€™s how Operation Paperclip got off the ground.
In the spring of 1945, Allied forces were closing in on Nazi Germany, and the end of the war in Europe was in sight. Officials started to make pâ€¦

entry.title: 8 ways to find calm in Thailand's larger-than-life capital city
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Bangkok may have a reputation as one of the worldâ€™s biggest concrete jungles, but in between the neon-lit streets, rooftop bars and crowded markets there are some glorious pockets of calm. The cityâ€™s network of canals help create breathing space among the tuk-tuk packed neighbourhoods, and thereâ€™s a surprising amount of green space in the cityâ€™s environs â€” accessible by boat, bike or on foot. Here are eight of our favourite hideaways.Â
One of several plush hotels lining the Chao Phraya River, the Riva Arun is noteworthy for its peaceful, top-floor terrace restaurant, Above Riva. You can ease into the day with breakfast or settle in for sunset cocktails, watching boats crisscross the river. The dinner menu goes bâ€¦

ğŸ’¬ æ–‡ç« é‡‘å¥
The APIï¼Œ which has evolved through five preview iterationsï¼Œ aims to simplify and provide developers with clearerï¼Œ safer frameworks for managing parallel tasksï¼Œ particularly when working with virtual threads. Developers now open a scope through static factory methodsï¼Œ such as `StructuredTaskScope.open()`ï¼Œ a change that clarifies defaults and paves the way for richer completion policies. Each fork launches a subtaskï¼Œ by default on a virtual threadï¼Œ returning a `Subtask` handle whose `get()` is safe only after `join()` completes. ğŸ“Š æ–‡ç« ä¿¡æ¯

entry.title: Traveling during hurricane season? Here's what you should know
entry.summary:
Tropical cyclones are unpredictable so being prepared and knowing your options in case of a storm are key when travelling during hurricane season. From what to pack to whether travel insurance will cover you, hereâ€™s what you need to know about travelling during tropical cyclones.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Long balmy days, sparkling turquoise waters â€” these are the classic ingredients of a tropical break. But risk going during the hurricane season and you could end up looking at a very different picture. It doesnâ€™t necessarily mean trips have to be off the agenda though. In fact, for some, off-season prices and the lack of crowds make hurricane season a particularly attractive time to travel. Hereâ€™s how best to prepare.
Collectiveâ€¦

entry.title: Join a homegrown family feast in Italy's Basilicata region
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Deft and swift, she forms millimetre-thick sheets, slicing them into ribbons that she wraps around her narrow rolling pin to shape the screw-like ssÃ«ppondapÃ²rtÃ« (the word for â€˜door hinge pinâ€™ in local dialect) or cuts into the roughly square-shaped takkÃ«nuÃ¨ddÃ«. Next, the remaining dough â€” an egg-free mix of semolina flour and 00 pasta flour â€” is divided and rolled into thin sausages. She cuts these into one- and two-finger-width pieces and presses them into cavatelli and orecchiette, her digits moving in a blur of speed. Maria Coppola Colucci has been working in the kitchen at this pace for two hours and the septuagenarian grandmother shows no sign of flagging.
â€œWe were in the garden first thing this morning digginâ€¦

entry.title: Field of Dreams: Football Breathes Life into Yemenâ€™s Camps
entry.summary: Every summer in Maâ€™rib, Yemen, a place marked by loss and uncertainty, a football tournament offers a rare kind of hope. For hundreds of displaced youth living across more than a dozen sites, itâ€™s a chance to unite, to belong, and to dream.

entry.title: Try this budget alternative to Canada's famous Rocky Mountaineer
entry.summary:
Completed in 1914 as the western end of the Grand Trunk Pacific Railway, the Skeena travels through some of British Columbiaâ€™s wildest backcountry, including the 24,700sq mile Great Bear Rainforest, the largest temperate forest on Earth. Crossing vast tracts of British Columbian wilderness, the Skeena is one of Canadaâ€™s most thrilling, and little-known, rail journeys.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
â€œLadies and gentlemen, weâ€™ll be making an unscheduled stop here to pick up another passenger,â€ announces train manager Alain Vermette. â€œIn fact, we need to back up. We just missed his stop.â€
Brakes squeal and gears grind as Via Rail Line 6 â€” better known as â€˜the Skeenaâ€™ â€” slows, shifts into reverse and trundles back down the track. A minute lâ€¦

entry.title: Where to see wildlife in Europe this summer
entry.summary:
Summer is the best time for wildlife-watching in Europe and spotting animals such as bears, wolves and lynx, is made possible thanks to knowledgable guides and various animal reintroduction schemes. From the FÄƒgÄƒraÈ™ Mountains of Romania to the teeming sea cliffs of St Kilda in Scotland, Europe is still home to staggering displays of summer wildlife. Whether youâ€™re searching for sperm whales, brown bears, dolphins or wolves, here are six of the best destinations to target.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Although quite densely populated, Europe isnâ€™t short of lonely island outposts, remote mountain ranges and dark, seemingly impenetrable forests â€” and many of them shelter world-class displays of animal activity. Youâ€™ll need to be well-equippedâ€¦

entry.title: Whatever happened to the samurai?
entry.summary:
The samurai, Japanâ€™s celebrated lineage of warriors, emerged in the Heian period (794-1185), when the rise of their status enabled them to mingle with the refined nobility living in the then-capital of Heian-kyÅ (Kyoto). Samurai fought in the ÅŒnin War and during the period of unrest that followed. From then on, the bushi, as the samurai were also called, made their mark on Japanese history with their exceptional fighting prowess, becoming emblematic of Japanese culture.
The high point of samurai history is often associated with the Tokugawa shogunate, also known as the Edo period (1603â€“1868), a time of peace, prosperity, isolationist policies, and cultural growth. This is the most studied era of Japanese history and the period in which novelists, filmmakers, and comic book creators teâ€¦

entry.title: This is the longest hiking trail in Central Asia
entry.summary:
Tourists prepare for a boating adventure on KÃ¶l-Suu (or Kel-Suu), a lake located in the heart of the Tian Shan mountain range in Kyrgyzstan. By summer's end, more than 600 miles will be added to the Kyrgyz Nomad Trail, granting hikers access to lesser-known parts of the country.
Adventurous hikers now have access to see a different side of Kyrgyzstan. TheÂ Kyrgyz Nomad TrailÂ (KNT) is a 1,243-mile (2,000-kilometer) long-distance hiking trail in northern and eastern Kyrgyzstan, which make it the longest trail network in Central Asia. Launched in June 2024, the KNTâ€”a network of 18 marked sectionsâ€”runs west to east passing through states (oblasts) such as Jalal-Abad, Naryn, and Issyk-Kul.
Along the trail, hikers also experienceÂ the beauty of KyrgyzstanÂ firsthand with natural landmaâ€¦

entry.title: Do chimpanzees have rhythm? Listen to their drumming.
entry.summary:
Chimpanzees drum and make calls to communicate. Two new studies have found they drum to send message across large distances and can create complex vocalizations. New research on the rhythmic drumming and complex calls of chimpanzees could point scientists to the origins of language.
â€œYou feel it in your body when they drumâ€”itâ€™s insanely impressive,â€ says Vesta Eleuteri.Â
Sheâ€™s a cognitive biologist at the University of Vienna who studies chimpanzee drumming and observed over 350 drumming performances like this in five African countries.
Chimpanzees in West Africa hold onto trees with their hands while kicking against roots with their feet, emitting powerful sounds that travel long distances, sometimes over a half mile.Â
â€œTheyâ€™re so fast sometimesâ€¦ their hands and feeâ€¦

entry.title: This tree's destruction prompted outrageâ€”and now a guilty verdict
entry.summary:
The Sycamore Gap tree grew in the dip of an ancient Roman wall. A lone tree growing along an ancient Roman wall was a beloved fixture in the landscape. Why did the Sycamore Gap treeâ€™s illegal felling spark so much emotion?
In the early hours of September 28, 2023, an act of violence and vandalism shocked the U.K.
The next day, news of the attack dominated social media and mainstream news coverage, leading to outpourings of grief, fury at its senselessness, and pilgrimages to the remote stretch of countryside where the crime took place.
This wasnâ€™t a human tragedy.
In the dark of night, a solitary sycamore tree was cut down at an iconic stretch of an ancient ruin known as Hadrianâ€™s Wall in Northumberland in north east England. The wall is nearly 2,000 years old and Â hâ€¦

entry.title: This Alaska volcano might erupt soon
entry.summary:
For the last year, Alaska's Mount Spurr has been showing signs of a potential eruption on the horizon. If an eruption happens, it would likely occur at Crater Peak, shown in the background of this summit photograph.  An explosion on Mount Spurr could generate massive cloud of ash, which could mess with airplanes and cause issues for humans.
Over the past 12 months, an Alaskan volcano named Mount Spurr has become noticeably agitated: Itâ€™s been swelling, quaking, and venting noxious gases. As it stands today, the evidence could point to a major explosive event on the horizonâ€”or the mountain might just be harmlessly blowing off some steam.
If an eruption were to happen, the good news is that there arenâ€™t any communities living on its slopes that would be smothered by scaldinâ€¦

entry.title: Why do so many animals â€˜glowâ€™ in UV light?
entry.summary:
Scorpions are one of many animals that appear to glow under ultraviolet (UV) light. Scientists are finding that photoluminescence is more common than previously suspected.  Animals with ultraviolet color patterns can be found all over nature. Hereâ€™s what we know about what purpose these patterns serve.
Shine an ultraviolet flashlight on flying squirrels, and they glow bright pink. Catch a scorpion on a full moon, and youâ€™ll notice that itâ€™s a haunting blue. Rays and sharks can turn neon green, while nearby coral come alive in electric reds.
And hawksbill sea turtles? Under ultraviolet light, they turn into glow-in-the-dark, underwater Christmas decorations, with both greens and reds arranged in overlapping chevrons.Â
Each of these glowing animals is an example oâ€¦

entry.title: Hereâ€™s your fix of cute baby animals cuddling with their moms
entry.summary:
PhotoÂ ArkÂ BabiesÂ is Joel Sartore's sixth book exploring the marvels of the animal world through his ongoing National GeographicÂ PhotoÂ ArkÂ project, a multi-year mission toÂ photograph animals in human care around the world, emphasizing those liable to be lost forever due to species extinction.
What is family to a seabird who soars alone over the open ocean, or to a primate who clings to its mother for years? Do animals have siblings, aunties, or cousins? Can they survive without any family at all?
Bearing and rearing young are central to the life cycle of nearly all creatures, whether done the way of the giant clamâ€”by releasing half a billion eggs into the vast sea, full stopâ€”or the koala, who provides long stretches of intense care. Parents of the animal kingdom are endlesslyâ€¦

entry.title: Sharing meals could be the key to better mental health
entry.summary:
The cuisines across the Mediterranean, Latin American, and Southeast Asian may vary, but the practice of sharing food and gathering around the table is so deeply rooted in these cultures that itâ€™s almost sacred. Meals are eaten together, plates are passed with intention, and no one rises until all are finished.
But in other parts of the world, communal dining has become a rarity. The idea of taking a full hour for lunch is met with skepticism, and even basic rituals like sharing a proper meal are brushed aside as indulgent. How has something so essential to our well-being become so easily dismissed?
According to the 2025 World Happiness Report, meal sharing ranks among the strongest predictors of well-being, comparable to factors like income and employment.
(The problem wiâ€¦

entry.title: The surprising real world uses of zombie fungi
entry.summary:
Even the largest insect bodies offer no refuge from parasitic fungi. This cicada, now a husk, has been consumed by a fungus. The specimen is part of the growing collection curated by mycologist JoÃ£o AraÃºjo at the University of Copenhagen, where researchers are uncovering the immense diversityâ€”and potentialâ€”of these microorganisms. Parasitic fungi have adapted to hijack some insects and nourish others. By learning their secrets, we may be able to use them to attack harmful pests.
Zombie fungi have become notorious in pop culture and from videos of them bursting through ants, but itâ€™s time for their redemption arc.
Scientists know very little about how zombie fungi work, but they and closely related fungi could help farmers kill costly pests like mealybugs and aphids. These pestâ€¦

entry.title: What itâ€™s like to run a marathon beyond the end of the world
entry.summary:
The writer, Nick Busca, crossing the finish line at the Antarctica Marathon. Before you can lace up for one of the worldâ€™s most remote races, youâ€™ll need to navigate wild seas, endure freezing temperatures, and embark on a journey that tests more than just your endurance.
â€œHold on tight. Itâ€™s gonna be wet. And itâ€™s gonna be bumpy.â€ Our Zodiac driver Steven Rose, who goes by Steve, doesnâ€™t sugarcoat it. I grab the line to my left and slide my goggles over my eyes.
The sea is choppy, and the water is a deep, intense blue that sends chills down my spine. The temperature is around 5Â°C (41Â°F), but the 30-knot winds hitting my face make it feel much colder.
As soon as Steve accelerates, the swells hit those at the front of the boat. I grimace: Running a marathon is hard enough â€¦

entry.title: When elephant moms need help, nannies step in
Why did the Pope pick Leo? Hereâ€™s why the name is so important
entry.summary:
Cardinal Robert Francis Prevost made history by becoming the first Roman Catholic pope from North America. Once elected, however, he chose a pontifical name steeped in hundreds of years of religious tradition: Pope Leo XIV.Â
As the number indicates, Prevost is the 14th pope with the name Leo. Pope Leo XIV will likely discuss his pontifical name in the coming days, but its significance is clear when looking at the pontificates of his predecessors. From Pope Leo I and his purported exchange with Attila the Hun to Pope Leo IX's role in the Great Schism of A.D. 1054, the pontifical name holds great importance within the Roman Catholic Church.Â
The name Leo means "lion" in Latin and carries with it a sense of regality, dignity, and leadership. Pope Leo I, the first of three popes inâ€¦

entry.title: U.S. Race and Justice Correspondent
entry.summary: Reuters is seeking a skilled and ambitious U.S.-based correspondent to lead coverage on the intersection of race, justice, gender and government. This journalist will pursue stories of global significance that will explore how policy decisions and programs impact communities across the country â€” and the drivers, or people, behind those decisions. As a U.S.-based correspondent [â€¦]

entry.title: OSINT Researcher
entry.summary: CNN is looking for a Researcher to join our Investigations team and will work alongside an ambitious crew of journalists to produce original stories that hold powerful people and institutions accountable, prompt change and right wrongs. The Visual Investigations (OSINT) Researcher will use open-source intelligence techniques to collect, analyze and verify data from publicly available [â€¦]

entry.title: Find your creative side in Toyama's living craft village in Japan
entry.summary:
Surrounded by mountains in central Japanâ€™s Toyama Prefecture, Inami lives and breathes wood. Out of a population of just 8,000, around 150 people work as woodcarvers and the town is a kind of open-air museum to showcase their skills. In a town hewn from wood, immerse yourself in traditional arts and get hands-on in a craft studio.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Keep your eyes peeled when wandering the stone-paved streets of Inami. The townâ€™s carpenters, of whom there are many, have tucked dozens of wooden carved cats into unexpected locations, from a svelte feline that doubles as a sweet shopâ€™s door handle to a pleased-looking puss pouring itself a cup while strategically positioned above a sake shopâ€™s door. Cat-spotting is just one playful â€¦

entry.summary: The UN World Food Programme (WFP) has warned that millions of people in West and Central Africa are facing record hunger as conflict, displacement, economic hardship and repeated extreme weather push the region towards a major crisis.

entry.title: Fish flee for their lives in rare video of bottom trawling
entry.summary: An aerial view of the impacts of bottom trawling on the ocean floor. The never-before-seen footage of sea creatures struggling in fishing nets is featured in National Geographicâ€™s new documentary Ocean with David Attenborough. As a cloud of destruction approaches, all the creatures in its path scramble desperately to get out of the wayâ€”fleeing for their lives. However fast they go, they can't outpace it. It looms closer and closer until it swallows them up. Although it may sound like a disaster movie, this is a scene from newly released rare footage of bottom trawlingâ€”a particularly destructive method of fishing in which a ship drags a heavy iron net across the seabed, blindly catching anything in its path. These vessels usually fish for just one speciesâ€”cod, haddoâ€¦

entry.title: The first U.S. pope? Rome reacts to a once impossible scenario
entry.summary:
Vatican CityAmid the ancient pomp and ceremony of the Vatican, bathed in the gorgeous light of a Roman spring evening, former Cardinal Robert Prevost has emerged onto the balcony of St. Peterâ€™s Basilica as the first U.S.-born pope in history. He has taken the papal name of Leo XIVâ€”a name that the vast crowd in St. Peterâ€™s Square took up with a spontaneous chant of â€œLe-on-e," the Italian version of the Latin Leo. Â
In the hour between the white smoke billowing from a chimney above the Sistine Chapel announcing that the 133 cardinal electors had made their choice shortly after 6 p.m. local time and Leoâ€™s appearance on the balcony, the streets around the Vatican filled with hurrying crowds, including groups of excited young monks and nuns who gathered up their robes to break into a digniâ€¦

entry.title: How to grow from painful experiences
entry.summary:
Erica Solove remembers December 30, 2021, like it was yesterday. She was at home in Superior, Colorado, a Boulder suburb at the foot of the Rockies. â€œIt was an extremely windy day,â€ she says. â€œHurricane-force winds. And we quickly realized itâ€™s not just wind coming down the mountain â€“ itâ€™s fire.â€ She grabbed her napping two-year-old daughter out of her crib while her husband scooped up their five-year-old son. The family got in the car, struggling to open the doors against the wind, and fled without wallets, coats, or even shoes. She remembers how half the sky was black with smoke, while the other half was a bright crystalline blue.
They were fleeing the Marshall Fire, the costliest in Colorado history. Her family lost everything. In the early weeks after the disaster, Solove experienâ€¦

entry.title: Why deadly night tornadoes are growing more common
entry.summary:
Tornadoes have long been ranked among the most dangerous weather events in the U.S., but those that strike after dark are significantly more deadly. Nearly twice as fatal as their daytime counterparts, nocturnal tornadoes are becoming more common as a warming climate shifts when and where severe storms form.
The risk is personal for Aaron Hill, a meteorologist and father of three. â€œI hate nocturnal tornadoes,â€ says Hill, who teaches at the University of Oklahoma. Every time a warning sounds at night, he faces the same gut-wrenching decision as many others across the Great Plains: wake the kids, or risk waiting too long.
â€œWe have this battle of, do we wake them up for something not to happen? Do we not wake them up and then rush to get them out? I feel so unprepared,â€ he says. â€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: Much of the data in this essay is drawn from the Religious Landscape Study (RLS). We also draw upon data collected from surveys conducted on Pew Research Centerâ€™s American Trends Panel (ATP) and data from the General Social Survey (GSS). We walk through the details of these data sources below. We also discuss how we [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Americansâ€™ Trust in One Another
entry.summary: Americans trust each other less than they did a few decades ago. We explore why this is, and why some are more trusting than others. The post Americansâ€™ Trust in One Another appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Nat Geo's ultimate guide to â€˜touching grassâ€™
entry.summary:
"Touch grass" doesn't have to be an insult. The term is frequently used on social media as a wake-up call to put down your phone and experience the real worldâ€”by, say, relaxing in long grass on a spring day. Science suggests there are serious mental health benefits to touching grass. We're something of an expert in the art of reconnecting with the outdoors. Hereâ€™s our ultimate guide to what the chronically online call â€œtouching grass.â€
If youâ€™re in the mood for a reality check, take a look at how much time youâ€™ve spent staring at your phone this week. Weâ€™ll waitâ€¦
Are you shocked? Slightly ashamed? Or perhaps inspired to spend less time brain rotting your way into the void?
Well, experts have one piece of advice for you: Touch grass.
Yes, literally. But also metaphoriâ€¦

entry.title: â€˜She cries in her sleepâ€™: Deeper crisis looms beneath devastation from Myanmar quake
entry.summary: AnÂ estimated 3,800 people have died as a result of the devastating earthquakes that struck Myanmar on 28 March. Six weeks on, the situation in Myanmar remains dire, with whole communities still traumatised and vulnerable.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN Security Council extends South Sudan mission amid rising instability
entry.summary: The Security Council has extended the mandate of the UN Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) for another year, as the worldâ€™s youngest nation teeters on the brink of renewed conflict.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: South Sudan urged to avoid slide to war, TÃ¼rk calls on EU not to weaken landmark law, Ukraine and Mali updates
entry.summary: The UN peacekeeping mission in South Sudan (UNMISS) together with the African Union mission there, and other key bodies collectively known as the Quartet, have raised the alarm over rising violence and political instability in South Sudan.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres welcomes election of Pope Leo â€˜at a time of great global challengesâ€™
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres welcomed the announcement of a new Pope on Thursday.

entry.title: UNRWA condemns â€˜stormingâ€™ of schools in East Jerusalem
entry.summary: The UN agency for Palestine refugees, UNRWA, has strongly condemned the forced entry by Israeli security forces into three of its schools in occupied East Jerusalem, describing it as a violation of childrenâ€™s right to education and safety.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights body rules Guatemala failed displaced Mayan Peoples
entry.summary: The UN Human Rights Committee has found that Guatemala did not follow through on promises to resettle and compensate Mayan Peoples who remain forcibly displaced.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Port Sudan: No let-up in drone attacks as UN chief urges peace
entry.summary: Amid reports that renewed drone strikes on a key Sudanese aid hub were thwarted late Wednesday, UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres added his voice to increasingly urgent calls for serious peace negotiations to end more than two years of war in Sudan.

entry.title: How Lanzarote's volcanic landscape has shaped island life
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Itâ€™s just an hour past sunrise when I reach the rim of Caldera Blanca, a steep-sided hulk of igneous rock on the western flank of Lanzarote. The sun casts a reddish wash over the land. Up here â€” some 1,500ft above the broiling swell of the Atlantic â€” the only sounds are the wind and the waves, but the whole island is spread out at my feet. In all directions are dozens of other peaks, silent mounds rising from the jagged flatlands.
Three centuries ago, the summit Iâ€™m standing on didnâ€™t even exist. In 1730, the ground began belching a morass of ash and lava across the island in a series of cataclysmic eruptions, covering almost a quarter of its entire area. Many villages had to be abandoned for good. The seismic actiâ€¦

entry.title: What creatures make these rare ocean gemstones?
entry.summary:
Beneath sea urchinsâ€™Â exterior spines, rounded skeletons called tests are jewels of color, texture, and symmetry. There are hundreds of urchin species, and theyâ€™re found in every ocean on Earth, from the intertidal zone to more than four miles below the surface. In 2018, Anders Hallan, a research associate at the Australian Museum in Sydney, began photographing urchin skeletons that had washed up on beaches or been collected by divers and those on fishing or research vessels. He created a composite image over the course of a week in 2024 using 76 individual photographs.
The project comes at a perilous moment for these creatures. Since 2022, sea urchins have been plagued by a scuticociliate, a single-celled pathogen that eats away at the animalsâ€™ soft tissue and makes their spines fall â€¦

entry.title: Inside Kowloon Walled Cityâ€”a lawless Hong Kong metropolis
entry.summary:
Until 1994, a tiny subsection of Hong Kong was dominated by a vertical cityâ€”a place so dense, it was hard to imagine how its 30,000 or more residents could survive there.
Known as Kowloon Walled City, the area was littered with trash, cluttered with crime, and renowned for its anarchy. Lawless and largely forgotten by both Chinese and Hong Kong officials, the city â€œhas always aroused curiosity and fear, and few dared venture inside,â€ historian Elizabeth Sinn writes in the Journal of the Hong Kong Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society.
But how did Kowloon Walled City become so chaoticâ€”and why did people choose to live there? Once called the â€œcity of darkness,â€ this area was so tangled and contested that its legacy still lives on decades after its eventual destruction. undefineâ€¦

entry.title: Here are 5 lesser-known California wine regions worth exploring
entry.summary:
Wine connoisseurs can travel beyond the famed Napa Valley wine region to explore other vineyards like this one in the Santa Ynez Valley, Calif. From the Temecula Valley to the Santa Cruz Mountains, these wine regions deliver more of the tailored experience you seek and less of the crowds.
When it comes to wine tasting in California, most people immediately think of Napa Valley, with its wineries and tasting rooms around every corner. If you look beyond this powerhouse region, you'll find wine destinations across the state, where the weekend traffic isn't as intense and you can get a more personalized wine tasting experience.Â Â
Cool winds from the San Francisco Bay flow 90 miles east to the town of Lodi, creating the perfect environment for grape growing. The town owes its eaâ€¦

entry.title: These daredevil women pilots helped beat Hitler in WWII
entry.summary:
The women Of Air Transport Auxiliary flew the biggest bombers and the sleekest fighters. Banned from flying in the U.S., these 25 American women headed to Britain to help ferry military aircraftâ€”and fascinated the public with their free-wheeling lives.
The United States barred women pilots from the armed forces during World War II, but that didnâ€™t stop 25 courageous young trailblazers. They bolted for Great Britain in 1942 to become the first American women to fly military aircraft.
The pilots have been mostly forgotten ever since. But during the war, they shook things up wherever they landed, prompting headlines like one in the New York Herald Tribune. The pilots, it said, â€œFly 121 Types of Planes, Sleep Wherever They Land, Find Romance and Tragedy.â€
No wonder the pâ€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 164 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from Feb. 24 to March 2, 2025. A total of 5,123 panelists responded out of 5,737 who were sampled, [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Americans on Healthy Food and Eating
entry.summary: About half of U.S. adults say healthiness of food is important when deciding what to eat. But taste and cost matter more. The post Americans on Healthy Food and Eating appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: It's conclave timeâ€”and frugality is in, extravagance is out
entry.summary: The Via dei Penitenziari, tucked between the ancient gate of the Vatican City and St. Peterâ€™s Square, is a busy stretch of pavement as the Catholic church prepares to elect the next pope. A smart young priest in a crisp black suit, and carrying a briefcase, weaves through the crowds as purposefully as a Milanese executive. â€œA Jesuit, doubtless,â€ murmurs my lunch companion, a veteran Vatican reporter. A couple of African nuns in blue tunics and home-knitted cardigans get caught in a human traffic jam as a corpulent padre with a heavy silver cross around his neck leads a gaggle of pilgrims. â€œSpaniards from the Order of the Holy Sepulchre,â€ to judge by the Jerusalem crosses on the breast of their matching black polo shirts. And the elderly guy in a rumpled black suit, plain priestâ€™s shirt, anâ€¦

entry.title: Are these popular salon treatments a health threat?
entry.summary:
Chemical hair straightening treatments promise smooth, straight hair, but studies have linked them to health issues. Chemical hair straighteners promise smooth, frizz-free hair, but research has linked these treatments to an increased risk of serious health conditions.
A few years ago, strange things began to happen to Merideth Pedack.
The Washington-based hairstylist found she could taste her clientsâ€™ deodorant on the back of her tongue, even from ten feet away. A sharp metallic smell clung to her nose throughout the day, and she started getting grinding headaches that seemed to last longer and longer with each passing week until one day they simply never stopped.Â Â
â€œThe pounding in my brain and skull and spine and eyes and ears. It was all day. It was all night,â€ says â€¦

entry.title: Views of Race, Policing and Black Lives Matter in the 5 Years Since George Floydâ€™s Killing
entry.summary: Roughly seven-in-ten Americans (72%) say the increased focus on race and racial inequality after Floydâ€™s killing did not lead to changes that improved the lives of Black people. And 54% say the relationship between Black people and police is about the same as before Floyd was killed. The post Views of Race, Policing and Black Lives Matter in the 5 Years Since George Floydâ€™s Killing appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: DPR Korea ploughing ahead with nuclear and ballistic missile programme
entry.summary: A top UN official has warned that the Democratic Peopleâ€™s Republic of Korea (DPRK) is ramping up its nuclear and missile programme in defiance of international law, as it moves into the final year of its military plan.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Port Sudan: Aid officials call for greater protection as drone attacks continue
entry.summary: The UN has renewed its call to end the brutal conflict in Sudan after a surge in drone strikes, including in Port Sudan â€” the vital hub and lifeline for humanitarian aid.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Absent faces, destroyed homes â€“ young students paint the pain of Gaza
entry.summary: Students displaced by the war in Gaza have been channeling their anguish into art in psychosocial support sessions provided by the UN agency that assists Palestine refugees, UNRWA.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: New horror in Gaza as double strike on school shelter kills 30
entry.summary: Grim details emerged on Wednesday of Israeli airstrikes on a UN-run school in Gaza sheltering 2,000 displaced people, which reportedly killed 30 Palestinians sheltering there.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo aid operation reaches Beni with food supplies for thousands
entry.summary: A UN food convoy has successfully delivered vital supplies to support tens of thousands of displaced people affected by escalating violence in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), according to humanitarian teams on the ground.

entry.title: How to save a desert oasisâ€”before it vanishes completely
entry.summary:
Driving south out of the Atlas Mountains into Moroccoâ€™s DrÃ¢a Valley, travelers find that the landscape becomes increasingly stark until the paved national highway vanishes into the desert at the oasis town of Mhamid el Ghizlane.
Sometimes known as the gateway to the Sahara, Mhamid and its surrounding villages are home to about 6,100 people. For generations, the settlement has straddled the DrÃ¢a River, with wispy tamarisk trees lining the road on the north bank of the river and palm plantations spreading out to the south. But today the concrete bridge built to span the water rises over a dry riverbed of sand and gravel. Tourists still come to Mhamid, drawn to camel treks, camping, and sandboarding. They arrive by the busload and make their way to hotels that offer swimming pools and maâ€¦

entry.title: Gathering Evidence and Documents in Conflict and War Zones â€” A MENA Case Study
entry.summary: Journalists working in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) are often on the frontlines of unfolding tragedies â€” from Gaza and Sudan to Syria, Yemen to Iraq. In these conflict and post-conflict settings, reporters may be some of the first to encounter potential evidence of war crimes. Their work can go beyond bearing witness [â€¦]

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: About Pew Research Centerâ€™s Spring 2024 Global Attitudes Survey Results for the survey are based on telephone, face-to-face and online interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup, Langer Research Associates, Social Research Centre and Verian. The results are based on national samples, unless otherwise noted. Here are more details about ourÂ international survey methodology and country-specific [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This analysis was produced by Pew Research Center as part of the Pew-Templeton Global Religious Futures project, which analyzes religious change and its impact on societies around the world. Funding for the Global Religious Futures project comes from The Pew Charitable Trusts and the John Templeton Foundation (grant 63095). This publication does not necessarily reflect [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 5. Religious importance and religious affiliation
entry.summary: By some measures, the worldâ€™s most religious countries are mostly in the Middle East, South and Southeast Asia, sub-Saharan Africa and Latin America. The post 5. Religious importance and religious affiliation appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Spiritual and religious practices
entry.summary: Some activities, such as prayer, are widespread. Others, such as fasting and lighting incense or candles, vary more by country. The post 4. Spiritual and religious practices appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Spells, curses and ways to see the future
entry.summary: Many around the globe think spells or curses can affect peopleâ€™s lives. Far fewer say they consult fortune tellers or horoscopes to see the future. The post 3. Spells, curses and ways to see the future appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Beliefs about the afterlife
entry.summary: In nearly every place surveyed, half or more say life after death is likely. Fewer believe in reincarnation or that ancestral spirits can affect their lives. The post 2. Beliefs about the afterlife appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. God, spirits and the natural world
entry.summary: Large majorities around the world say they believe in God. Read about beliefs in spiritual presence â€œbeyond the natural world,â€ and in animals and nature. The post 1. God, spirits and the natural world appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Believing in Spirits and Life After Death Is Common Around the World
entry.summary: Belief in an afterlife, God and spirits in nature is widespread globally. Older adults are more likely than younger adults to believe in God. The post Believing in Spirits and Life After Death Is Common Around the World appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Amelia Earhart broke barriersâ€”until her mysterious death
entry.summary:
Amelia Earhart with her airplane. Earhart was an American aviatrix, making history as the first woman to cross Atlantic. From a curious Midwestern girl to a legendary aviator, Amelia Earhart's life was a daring pursuit of freedom, flight, and self-definition. 
  When Amelia Earhart stepped into the cockpit of her Lockheed Electra in June 1937, her sights were set on an accomplishment no woman had ever madeâ€”a female-piloted solo flight around theÂ globe.Â  Newspaper reporters crowded around the plane, documenting everything from her blue eyes to her bobbed hair to her pre-flight banter about her airplaneâ€™s fuel capacity and speed. Though many of the reporters asked about the potential danger of her trip, she shrugged off their questions. â€œIt is to be a safe and sâ€¦

entry.title: How to design a city to improve your mental health
entry.summary:
Designed to enhance accessibility and offer new perspectives, Denmarkâ€™s Camp Adventure Forest Tower draws visitors into the canopy in a way that feels both immersive and restorative. Itâ€™s part of a growing movement to design public spaces that encourage people to gather, linger, and connect. Experts say small changes in our neighborhoodsâ€”like where we sit, walk, or congregateâ€”can make a big difference in how connected we feel to those around us.
Erin Peavey was four months pregnant when she lost her mother to cancer. After her daughter was born in January 2019, the loneliness set in. Her mother had been her rock, a source of steady support. Now, home alone with a newborn and her husband working full time, Peavey clung to a piece of advice her mother had always given her: stay conneâ€¦

entry.title: This island has a month-long holiday celebration
entry.summary:
Bermuda celebrates its heritage throughout the month of May, from jazz performances to art showcases to curated historical tours.  Bermuda Day is technically held on the fourth Friday in May, but one day isnâ€™t really enough to celebrate the islandâ€™s cultural heritage. Hereâ€™s how it began, how it evolved, and how you can take part.
Bermuda Day, a holiday held on the fourth Friday in May each year in Bermuda, kicks off the island's start of summer and marks the rise in water and air temperatures, signaling to Bermudians that it's acceptable to swim in the ocean.
An all-day celebration takes place, not just to signify the warm weather, but to celebrate the islandâ€™s cultural heritage.
After decades of civil unrest and protest, which reached a climax in 1977, a Royal Coâ€¦

entry.title: Internet Roadtrip, where the community votes where to go at each step
entry.summary: What if you were on a roadtrip and every ten seconds a largeâ€¦ Tags: crowds, Neal Agarwal, road trip, voting

entry.title: The best evidence yet that gladiators fought lions: a bite mark
entry.summary:
Artists have long depicted Roman gladiators battling it out against big cats as you can see in this mosaic created in A.D. 320 in Rome. However, there has never been any physical evidence to suggest that this actually happenedâ€”until now. For the first time, bite marks made by a large cat, possibly an African lion, have been identified on the bones of what is believed to be an ancient Roman gladiator.
Gladiators fighting lions is among the more enduring images of the arenas of ancient Rome. But other than depictions in mosaics and carvings, along with a few mentions in ancient texts, there is virtually no physical evidence that it actually occurred. Until now.
For the first time, bite marks made by a large cat, possibly an African lion, have been identified on the bones of whatâ€¦

entry.title: UN Secretary-General urges military restraint from India, Pakistan
entry.summary: The UN chief has expressed deep concern over Indian military operations across the Line of Control and the international border with Pakistan.

entry.title: Lives of pregnant women and newborns at risk as funding cuts impact midwifery support
entry.summary: Midwives are vital frontline workers who can provide up to 90 per cent of essential sexual, reproductive, maternal, and newborn health services â€“ from safely delivering babies to caring for survivors of sexual violence.

entry.title: Security Council urged to stand firm as Bosnia and Herzegovina faces deepening crisis
entry.summary: A recent rise in tensions in Bosnia and Herzegovina has sparked an â€œextraordinary crisisâ€ as the country continues to emerge from the shadows of the Balkan wars 30 years ago, the UN Security Council heard on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza: UN aid teams reject Israelâ€™s â€˜deliberate attempt to weaponize aidâ€™
entry.summary: The reported Israeli proposal to deliver humanitarian supplies through hubs controlled by the military would be a breach of the core principles of neutral, impartial and independent aid delivery, the UN said on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Hospital bombing deepens bleak situation for war-weary South Sudanese
entry.summary: Aid teams in South Sudan warned on Tuesday that repeated attacks on healthcare including the bombing of a hospital in eastern Jonglei state at the weekend are just the latest of the â€œmultiple vulnerabilitiesâ€ the countryâ€™s people face.

entry.title: Exhausted Sudanese flee into Chad as fighting escalates
entry.summary: Thousands of exhausted Sudanese refugees continue to flee fighting in search of safety inÂ neighbouring Chad, aid teams said on Tuesday, as a third day of drone strikes ripped into the city of Port Sudan.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: More than 30-year difference in life expectancy highlights health inequities
entry.summary: The underlying causes of poor health often stem from factors such as lack of quality housing, education and job opportunities, according to a new report on the social determinants of health equity.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Alarmingâ€™ slowdown in human development - could AI provide answers?
entry.summary: The progress of human development â€“ as measured by peopleâ€™s freedoms and well-being â€“ has remained sluggish since the major shock of the COVID-19 pandemic. A UN study released on Tuesday finds that used in the right way, artificial intelligence could be a powerful tool to improve millions of lives.

entry.title: How to plan a food trip to Brussels
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
With bags of history, three official languages and the headquarters of both the EU and NATO, Brussels is an eclectic city â€”Â and it has a diverse food scene to match. Classic Belgian cuisine centres on simple ingredients and hearty eating â€” and plenty of restaurants keep that trusted formula alive.
In recent years, chefs and restaurateurs who used to flock to the likes of Ghent and Antwerp have been gravitating towards the capital. At Restaurant Aster, TÃºbo Logier and Ydris Gryson have created tasting menus using only local fish and vegetables cooked over fire, while Florent Ladeyn and Jordan Joubert of Klok have focused on sustainability, presenting dishes such as roasted celeriac with beurre noisette.
The groâ€¦

entry.title: These birds carry a toxin deadlier than cyanide
entry.summary:
The variable pitohui, a poisonous bird, captured in mist net on the outskirts of Wanang Village in Papua New Guinea in 2018. New Guinea is home to some of the worldâ€™s most toxic birds. Why they contain poison, and how they withstand the it is still a source of scientific mystery.
In the summer of 1989, Jack Dumbacher was a fresh-faced ornithologist-in-training on his maiden expedition to the lush rainforests of Papua New Guinea. One sticky afternoon, he noticed an unusual bird with gaudy black-and-orange feathers entangled in his mist nets. But as Dumbacher tried to set it free, the hooded pitohui scratched him.
Â â€œTheyâ€™re jay-sized birds with needle-sharp claws and bills,â€ says Dumbacher, who instinctively put the cut to his lips. â€œMy mouth started to tingle and burn, and thenâ€¦

entry.title: 5 hidden gems that show off Taiwanâ€™s wild side
entry.summary:
Tourists looking to experience Taiwan beyond its capital city, Taipei, should consider a road trip to visit places like Alishan to witness the sunrise glow over a sea of clouds. This phenomenon occurs when dense, low-lying clouds appear like a sea from a high vantage point such as Xiaoliyuanshan Lookout. For an alternative to the fast-paced capital and its crowded tourist haunts, consider the countryâ€™s small towns, shaped by incredible landscapes and cultural traditions.
To many travelers, a trip to Taiwan begins and ends in Taipei, for its dense night markets and syrupy-sweet bubble tea. But beyond the capitalâ€™s crush of scooters and skyscrapers lies an island defined not just by its food, but by its astonishing biodiversity.Â
More than half of Taiwan is forested with ecosystâ€¦

entry.title: 7 simple science-backed rules for living longer
entry.summary:
Humans have long tried to cheat death. And over the last 40 years, this collective obsession with longevity has led to landmark scientific breakthroughs and a booming anti-aging industry.
Scientists are chasing novel interventions to turn back the clock, while health-conscious biohackers are volunteering as lab ratsâ€”taking drugs like rapamycin and â€œyoung bloodâ€ plasma infusions in hopes of staying forever young. Annually, the average American spends more than $6,000 on wellness.
(Can aging be cured? Scientists are giving it a try.)
Scientists are closer than ever to cracking the code of aging, yet the broader field of longevity is awash with misinformation. To set the record straight, Eric Topol, a pioneering cardiologist and one of the worldâ€™s top-cited scientists, wrote Suâ€¦

entry.title: Visit Jalisco, Mexico, where the story of tequila begins
entry.summary:
The family-owned Tequila Fortaleza uses blue agave to make their tequila. From Guadalajara to AmatitÃ¡n, Jaliscoâ€™s tequila producers donâ€™t just make great spiritsâ€”they preserve its rich cultural heritage.
Tequila is the fastest growing spirits category in the United States, and a truly artisanal agricultural spirit with a unique Mexican terroir and a culture all its own. According to the Distilled Spirits Council of the United States' (DISCUS) 2025 Annual Economic Briefing, sales of the popular agave-based spirit grew by 2 percent from 2023 to 2024, leaving the rest of the bottles in the dust. Yet few of us know how tequila is produced and the rich heritage behind it.
A visit to Jalisco, where tequila is made (and mariachi-style music was born), provides an excellent peek intâ€¦

entry.title: 10 of the best new hotels in Lisbon
entry.summary:
A surge of innovative openings in the wake of the pandemic has injected new glamour into the romantic port cityâ€™s hotel scene.
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Portugalâ€™s capital has taken its growing popularity with city-breakers in its stride â€” antique trams rattle on, fado folk musicians still sing mournfully in low-lit bars and bakers continue to turn out flaky pasteis de nata. But the influx of visitors has quickened the cityâ€™s pulse; Portuguese chefs are pushing boundaries and artisans are opening new gallery spaces. Meanwhile, hoteliers are flexing their creativity too, putting lesser-known neighbourhoods like Lapa, Amoreiras and PrÃ­ncipe Real on the map. The past five years have seen a proliferation of bold hotel openings, from renovated â€¦

entry.title: What is storm-watching and where should you try it?
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Thereâ€™s nothing new in feeling awe in the face of natureâ€™s grandeur. The Romantics were enraptured by it back in the 19th century. English artist JMW Turner stirred the soul by painting brooding skies of biblical proportions, while philosopher Immanuel Kant explored the sublime â€” that profound blend of terror and wonder evoked by observing natural phenomena like a raging thunderstorm.
However, curated storm-watching tourism didnâ€™t really take off until 1996, when the original of cult-classic movie Twister sparked a whirlwind of interest in extreme weather. That same year, the Wickaninnish Inn opened its doors in Tofino, on the rugged western coast of Vancouver Island. Inspired by childhood memories of marvelling atâ€¦

entry.title: In India, an outlawed spirit is making a comeback
entry.summary:
At The Oberoi Vindhyavilas, a luxury wildlife resort to the north in Bandhavgarh Tiger Reserve in India, guests are greeted with a welcome drink crafted with mahua, local herbs and soda. Mahua, an ancient liquor, was once condemned during colonial rule, but a change in the law and an enterprising local bar community have led to the spiritâ€™s revivalâ€¯â€” to the benefit of Indigenous communities.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Spring has arrived in the jungles of Madhya Pradesh and the forest is bursting with every shade of green. Fresh shoots sprout from gnarled tree trunks as life begins anew after the long winter. In the distance, the birdsong is punctuated by a peacockâ€™s wails. Whatâ€™s really holding my attention, though, is the smell â€” a distâ€¦

entry.title: Go eye-to-eye with humpbacks on this Vancouver Island kayak tour
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Suddenly, I hear it: a rush of air and water so powerful that it sounds like a waterfall. Itâ€™s the unmistakable exhalation of a whale â€” explosive, resonant and coming from somewhere behind my kayak. Tentatively, I turn my head.
I spot it immediately: itâ€™s a humpback, rising from the water like a shadowy wave about to crest. Its massive, slate-coloured body glitters briefly in the morning light, before it sinks back into the depths, just as quickly as it had emerged. Soon, the ripples left behind by its mighty flukes fade, and itâ€™s like it was never there.
For a moment, Iâ€™m too stunned to paddle. Compared to the whale, which stretches roughly 40 feet from tip to tail, IÂ am tiny â€” a speck bobbing in an orange kaâ€¦

entry.title: Beach break in Belgium? Try Ostend
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The seaside city of Ostend is something of a curiosity. It was heavily bombed in the Second World War, and now its architecture juxtaposes Belle Ã‰poque-era townhouses and mid-century apartment blocks. Thereâ€™s the occasional oddity, like the neo-classical Royal Galleries, a seafront arcade, or modernist Kursaal, Europeâ€™s largest casino. And happily, some older dwellings have survived, too.
Take the Spanish Inn, a live music bar with a gabled roof. This is one of the cityâ€™s earliest buildings, last rebuilt in 1729. Within the red glow of its rear saloon, Flemish crooners perform to a crowd of locals, from young couples huddled in corners to older regulars slow-dancing.
The barâ€™s the perfect introduction to theâ€¦

entry.title: How to explore Paris from the seat of a bicycle
entry.summary:
Travelers can explore Parisâ€™s famed attractions from the seat of a bike and visit some of the cityâ€™s less-touristed neighborhoods, too. With some planning, tourists can cover the City of Lights like Parisians, on two wheels. Hereâ€™s a four-step guide on how to do it.
Biking is the new transportation revolution underway in Paris. This is good news for visitors, as I learned during a week of rediscovering my former hometown by bike. Over the past five years, the cityâ€™s dynamic mayor,Â Anne Hidalgo, has sparked a green transformation by adding more than 600 miles of dedicated cycling paths, installing over 21,000Â VÃ©libâ€™ city bikes, and implementing draconian limits on car traffic. That means itâ€™s easier than ever to enjoy the ride.Â Â Â
Notably, several keyÂ transportation arteriesâ€”liâ€¦

entry.title: Chaos and Credibility: A Snapshot of How AI Is Impacting Press Freedom and Investigative Journalism
entry.summary: GIJN offers a snapshot of how watchdog reporters are confronting algorithmic abuses and misinformation while also employing AI as a key newsroom tool.

entry.title: UN warns of growing humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza
entry.summary: The UN and partners on Sunday issued a stark warning over the deepening humanitarian crisis in Gaza, as Israeli authorities maintain a near-total blockade on the delivery of aid for a ninth consecutive week.
