entry.title: Black dandyism, this year's Met Gala theme, explained
entry.summary:
Throughout history, fashion has served as a fundamental political tool. Christian Diorâ€™s â€œNew Lookâ€ dresses signaled post-war optimism in the â€˜40s; women wore miniskirts in the â€˜60s to assert their own liberation; and Black Panthers made berets part of their uniforms in the â€˜70s. However, very few, if any, politically charged fashions can match the vitality and enduring spirit of Black dandyism.
The movement started with white British dandies, but Black communities eventually adopted it to challenge stereotypes, assert their own individualism and freedoms, and continuously bend fashion trends to their will. Black dandyism has transcended eras, and its impact still rings throughout culture today.
â€œDandyism travels through lots of time and space,â€ says Tonya Blazio-Licorish, authorâ€¦

entry.title: These Korean women have evolved traits to survive in frigid water
entry.summary:
A group of women around 70 years old laugh and sing on a beach in Jeju, an island off South Korea, preparing to spend the day diving for shellfish. Moments later, theyâ€™ll plunge into frigid waters as cold 50Â°F, diving down as deep as 32 feet and gathering their catch from the sea floor before quickly ascending. Theyâ€™ll do so without oxygen masks, diving and resurfacing for as long as five hours a day.
â€œThey now wear wetsuits, but up until the 1980s they were diving in these cotton bodysuits,â€ says Melissa Ilardo, geneticist at the University of Utah, who has been working with these women.
Called the Haenyeo, these divers carry on a matrilineal tradition of diving, even while pregnant.
Their impressive abilities are due partly to lifelong training that allows them to hold theâ€¦

entry.title: The problem with â€˜happinessâ€™
entry.summary:
Whether or not a person is happy is often linked with their overall well-being. But some researchers argue it's not the only metric for a good life. 
Researchers are still figuring out how people define well-being across countries and cultures. Happiness is a factor, but itâ€™s probably not the only one. If you ask someone what makes their life good, many people might respond with a list of things that make them happy. But not everyone measures their lives with happiness, and some people value happiness more than others. Humans have struggled to define the ingredients for a good life or for well-being in terms beyond simple happiness for millennia. Aristotle famously distinguished between hedonia, which refers to pleasure, and eudaimonia, which refers to a deeper, longeâ€¦

entry.title: 14 iconic beaches you should visit in your lifetime
entry.summary:
No matter their shape, their body of water, or the power of their waves, beaches provide an escape. From pink sand to green sand to star-shaped sand, these beaches are not to be missed.
From Hawaii's PapakÅlea Beach to Butiama Beach in Tanzania to Reynisfjara in Iceland, there are many incredible beaches all over the world. The new National Geographic book,Â 100 Beaches of a Lifetime, explores all of these destinations and more. Here are 14 beaches that are worth traveling for.
Japanâ€™s lushest, warmest, most tropical region, Okinawaâ€™s Yaeyama Islands are home to an unusual beach phenomenon: star sand. Closer to Taiwan than it is to the bigger islands of Japan, Taketomijima is among Japanâ€™s southernmost, westernmost inhabited islands. It is also one of the few places in thâ€¦

entry.title: How to plan a classic summer adventure in the Alps
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Mother Nature had one of her wildest moments shaping the Alps, which thrust up millions of years ago when the African and Eurasian tectonic plates collided. These peaks rip across Central Europe for 700 miles in a whirl of limestone turrets, glacier-frosted summits, dense forests and misty waterfalls. AsÂ they do, they run through eight countries â€” Monaco, France, Italy, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Austria, Germany and Slovenia â€” and around mighty rivers like the Rhine and Po.
These mountainsâ€™ rugged terrain and ever-changing weather once struck fear into those who had to cross them. Hannibal led his Carthaginian army and 37 elephants across rocky, icy heights to invade Italy in 218 BCE. Countless blizzard-battling â€¦

entry.title: How the Silk Roads became the connection between east and west
entry.summary: In A.D. 166, Chinese chroniclers recorded that ambassadors from the Roman emperor Marcus Aurelius presented themselves at the imperial court of Luoyang in east-central Chinaâ€”and were given an unusual welcome. The travelers had come via Malaysia, followed the coasts of Thailand and Vietnam, and docked at a Chinese port at the mouth of the Red River in the Gulf of Tonkin. Then, escorted by Chinese military authorities, they traveled overland for another 1,200 miles or so, passing numerous fortresses and walled cities. Anticipation at the Chinese court mounted as the travelers grew closer. The Chinese had long been aware that the Roman Empire existed; they knew it as Da Qin, â€œthe Great Chinaâ€ and considered it to be equal in power to their own empire. But this was the first time direct contacâ€¦

entry.title: Are the world's rivers dying? Author Robert Macfarlane thinks so
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Can you explain the concept of a river as a living being? At the heart of the book is the idea that rivers have lives, deaths â€“â€“ and even rights. It asks readers to imagine rivers in these terms, and to see what consequences flow from that re-imagining. The book is a journey into the history, futures, places and possibilities of this ancient, urgent idea.
I know that the notion of a river as 'alive' is a searching, confronting one, especially to those of us raised in the traditions of rationalism. It strikes at the anthropocentric core of many of our assumptions. But if you find it hard to imagine a river as alive, try imagining a dead or dying river. We know what this looks like, what it feels like: fish floating â€¦

entry.title: How to get enough vitamin D
entry.summary:
Vitamin D is a key nutrient for health. Not only does it help keep your bones strong, but it also assists with muscle and immune function. Yet, vitamin D stands at the center of a hotly debated wellness paradox.
Researchers agree that we generally arenâ€™t getting enough vitamin D, but they canâ€™t see eye to eye on how much is actually â€œenough,â€ what levels constitute a deficiency, or what benefitsâ€”if anyâ€”supplements provide, particularly for young and otherwise healthy people.
Advice on how to get vitamin D is also conflicting. Sunlight is the best source, but weâ€™re told to cover up to avoid skin cancer. Then weâ€™re advised to eat a diet rich in vitamin D even though most foods donâ€™t contain enough of it.Â
Now, research published in April 2025 in the journal Nutrients is addingâ€¦

entry.title: Portraits of San Diego: a culture of happiness
entry.summary:
National Geographic Photographer Kiliii YÃ¼yan is no stranger to travel, often spending months around the globe to understand the world through storytelling and photography. His adventures have taken him high above the Arctic Circle to the depths of tropical waters, capturing imagery of lionfish and other animals.Â
On a recent trip to San Diego, California, he took his storytelling prowess across the city to learn more about the culture, green and blue spaces, and community. What he found was that the cityâ€™s infectious optimism offered a different kind of thrill. Portraits of San DiegoLearn how this southern California city radiates an infectious brand of joy through the eyes of locals. â€œItâ€™s really hard not to feel the joy,â€ YÃ¼yan says of his time in Americaâ€™s finest city. â€œâ€¦

entry.title: Can you stand on one leg for 10 seconds? The answer matters for aging.
entry.summary:
If you canâ€™t comfortably stand on one leg for 10 seconds, your body may be trying to tell you something. â€œBeing able to stand on one leg is one of the most predictive measurements for aging,â€ says Clayton Skaggs, founder of the Central Institute for Human Performance (CIHP), the Karel Lewit Clinic, and Curious Gap Labs.
A 2024 Mayo Clinic study found that the ability to maintain balance standing on one leg indicates how well a person is aging more than strength or gait. Not only does it let us in on someoneâ€™s neuromuscular health, but it can also be a signal of other ailments.Â
â€œWe utilize [balance] diagnostically to rule in or rule out other diseases,â€ says Paraminder Padgett, a neurological clinical specialist and physical therapy clinical supervisor at Dartmouth Hitchcock Mediâ€¦

entry.title: The strange role worms play in the birth of baby squid
entry.summary:
An opalescent squidâ€™s experience of motherhood is almost cruelly brief. Towards the end of her life, she engages in a dramatic reproductiveÂ spectacleÂ where, under the glowing moon, a mating frenzy draws large numbers ofÂ Doryteuthis opalescensÂ into the shallows to spawn. Itâ€™s a relentless, disorienting ritual characterized by clouds of banana-sized cephalopods flashing red armsâ€”a mating signalâ€”and blending together in a haze.
â€œThe seabed and canyon slope, normally a stable point of reference, shifted underneath us as the squid melded in a living current,â€ says underwater photojournalist Jules Jacobs, who was there to document the story of the mating phenomenon off La Jolla Shores, California, in an eventÂ that can be witnessed at night, typically once a year, if at all. The mating eventâ€¦

The survey was conducted from March 24 to March 30, 2025. A total of 3,605 panelists responded out of 4,045 who were sampled, [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.summary: When asked which country is the top threat to the U.S., 42% name China. A quarter name Russia, but this share has grown since last year. The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.summary: Which country poses the greatest threat to the U.S.? Roughly four-in-ten Americans (42%) say China poses the greatest threat to the U.S. when asked in an open-ended question. Russia is named by the next-largest share (25%). Smaller shares say no country (4%), the U.S. itself (3%) or Iran (2%) is the greatest threat. One-in-five say [â€¦] The post 3. Americansâ€™ views of allies and threats appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. The United Statesâ€™ standing in the world
entry.summary: Americans generally say the U.S. is respected and that it's economy and military are powerful, but they think its global influence is getting weaker. The post 2. The United Statesâ€™ standing in the world appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.summary: Americans are split on whether the U.S. should be active in world affairs or focus on problems at home. There are also partisan gaps in support for different foreign aid types. The post 1. International engagement and support for foreign aid appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.summary: Most Americans say the U.S. should give humanitarian aid to other countries, and majorities endorse aid supporting economic development and democracy. The post Majorities of Americans Support Several â€“ But Not All â€“ Types of Foreign Aid appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Methodology: Asian American Fact Sheets
entry.summary: The analysis presented in Pew Research Centerâ€™s Asian American fact sheets and accompanying blog posts combines the latest data available from multiple data sources. The post Methodology: Asian American Fact Sheets appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Could this be the end of menopause as we know it?
entry.summary:
"We don't have to accept menopause as destiny,â€ says Kutluk Oktay, an ovarian biologist and director of the Yale School of Medicine and Director of Laboratory of Molecular Reproduction and Fertility Preservation. Oktay, a leading researcher in fertility preservation, is one of the many scientists in the race to end menopause as we currently understand it.Â
For most women, menopause means a gradual decline of progesterone and estrogen beginning in their mid-40s. The menopausal transition, or perimenopause, can last between two and eight years, and even up to a decade, before menopause, the point at which a womanâ€™s menstrual period has stopped for a year. During perimenopause, women can experience a range of associated symptoms, including hot flashes to night sweats, pain during sex, joâ€¦

entry.title: Why running vacations are the next big travel trend
entry.summary:
Itâ€™s almost sunset, and the waterfront MÅ±egyetem Wharf is just beginning to stir. The autumn heat, heavy as a weighted blanket, lingers over Budapest, yet a peculiar anticipation hangs in the air as hundreds of people gather for the Generali Night Run BudapestÂ in late August.
The 13-mile route winds through the Hungarian capitalâ€™s heart, taking runners up a 100-meter hill, past the towering Buda Castle, beneath the grand arches of the Chain Bridge, and along the lower embankment, where the illuminated Parliament, Margaret Bridge, and echoing Tunnel unfold like a moving postcard. As the sun bleeds into the Danube, the rhythmic pulse of live bands and the roar of spectators transform the city into a festival of motion and adrenaline, with the night sky as a dramatic backdrop.
Distaâ€¦

entry.title: Britainâ€™s most remote mainland pub is well worth the two-day hike
entry.summary:
Hiker Duncan Lomax travels along the Cape Wrath Trail, usually a 14-day trek from Fort William to Cape Wrath on the northern tip of Scotland. Tucked between sea and mountain, The Old Forge was once a cherished endpoint for hikersâ€”now, revived by the hands of locals, adventurers are coming back to this iconic watering hole.
We were dropped off at the end of theÂ UK's longest dead-end road. It felt like we had lost contact with the rest of the world. The wilds ofÂ Scotlandâ€™sÂ KnoydartÂ region stretched before usâ€”primal, remote, and magnetic. Somewhere out there layÂ The Old Forge, Britain's most remote mainland pub in the tiny village ofÂ Inverie. My partner Ines and I love a challenge. But before ordering drinks at the bar, we had two days of hiking aheadâ€”through some of the Highlands' toâ€¦

entry.title: This British breakfast classic originated in India
entry.summary:
Kedgeree recipes tend to fall into two camps: a low-waste version suitable for home cooks and a richer, more lavish rendition that would please a royal court. Originating in India during colonial rule and inspired by a traditional dish containing lentils, this combination of rice, smoked fish and egg has become a breakfast favourite in the UK.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Smoked fish flaked into gently spiced rice, topped with egg â€” kedgeree is a beloved breakfast dish thatâ€™s also enjoyed for brunch, lunch and dinner around the UK. Yet its origins can be traced back to India, centuries ago.
Itâ€™s derived from khichdi, a one-pot rice and lentil dish synonymous with both comfort and celebration in South Asia. The earliest written refereâ€¦

entry.title: Where does vanilla flavoring come from? Probably not beavers.
entry.summary:
The North American beaver, the largest rodent on the continent, can weigh up to 70 pounds. Castoreum, a substance from sacs near a beaverâ€™s anus, has been used in human products for more than 2,000 years. Some wonder if it's still an ingredient on today's grocery shelves.
Are there beaver secretions in your vanilla ice cream?
News articles or food influencers on social media might have you believe that castoreum, a yellow, syrupy substance from the castor sacs near aÂ beaverâ€™s anus, is used as everyday vanilla flavoring, disguised as â€œnatural.â€ According to some of these sources, beaver castor is an ingredient in everything from vanilla ice cream to strawberry-flavored oatmeal.
But experts say this couldnâ€™t be further from the truth. While people have used castoreum for meâ€¦

entry.title: How Cowboy Carter reminds us of the Black roots of country music
entry.summary:
Charley Pride, the first Black artist to have a number one country record, achieved immense success in the genre during the 1960s and 1970s, despite facing prejudice and racial discrimination. Artists like Beyonce and Lil Nas X are drawing mainstream attention to a tradition that is alive and wellâ€”thanks to the contributions and innovations of generations of Black musicians.
As BeyoncÃ© kicks off her Cowboy Carter world tour, her embrace of country music is reigniting conversations about the genreâ€™s Black rootsâ€”and the pioneers too often left out of its history.
Since BeyoncÃ© previewed Cowboy Carter during her Super Bowl commercial and released the album in March 2024â€”the second act of her Renaissance trilogyâ€”the cultural response has been electric. The Grammy-winning album spoâ€¦

entry.title: 6 Las Vegas Day Trips You Have to Experience
entry.summary:
Some of Las Vegasâ€™s most fascinating attractions lie just outside the city center. Within a few hoursâ€™ drive of the home of some of the worldâ€™s best entertainment, travelers will find historic landmarks, unique communities and dramatic natural wonders.
National Geographic photographer Keith Ladzinski has built a career out of finding the best adventures around the world. But on his most recent road trip through some of Nevadaâ€™s lesser-known regions, the abundance of adventures surprised him.Â When it comes to outdoor recreation, it is an absolute all-star state. Between rock climbing in Arrow Canyon, exploring long-abandoned ghost towns, and stargazing under stunning night skies, Ladzinski discovered the joy that comes from discovering places that might only whisper for yourâ€¦

entry.title: Your next adventure: Tokyo, Japan
entry.summary:
Thereâ€™s a talent to making things beautiful, and in Japan, thereâ€™s a word for it. Monozukuri, which translates to â€œcraftsmanshipâ€, speaks to the countryâ€™s devotion to high-quality and often visually mesmerizing creations. Precision, patience, and artistry are highly prized, and across Japanâ€™s eateries, markets, studios, and workshops, travelers are invited to join in.
On a recent journey to Tokyo, National Geographic photographer Jonathan Irish explored hidden gems, bustling neighborhoods, and vibrant cultural districts in this lively, cosmopolitan metropolis, and found that monozukuri abounds.
â€œDespite Tokyo's rapid growth and modern landscape, the city's rich history of craftsmanship remains a timeless part of its identity today,â€ says Irish. â€œI came away with a strong imprâ€¦

entry.title: WHO chief laments most disruptive cuts to global health funding â€˜in living memoryâ€™
entry.summary: As sudden budget cuts severely impact global health funding, prolonged conflicts around the world are fuelling disease outbreaks and posing a serious threat to public health, the head of the World Health Organization (WHO) warned on Thursday.

entry.title: Sudan: UN rights chief appeals for greater protection of civilians in besieged El Fasher
entry.summary: More than 500 civilians have been killed in North Darfur state, Sudan, over the past three weeks, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Afghanistan: Taliban restrictions on womenâ€™s rights intensify
entry.summary: Afghanistanâ€™s Taliban rulers have followed through on decrees aimed at erasing women from public life in the country and restricting their freedom of movement, the UN mission to the country (UNAMA) said in its latest human rights report published on Thursday covering the first quarter of 2025.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Anthrax outbreak compounds security crisis in eastern DR Congo
entry.summary: An anthrax outbreak is compounding the worsening security situation in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), driving up humanitarian needs and further limiting access to basic services. The escalating crisis is also widening critical gaps in healthcare and protection, amid a broader surge in infectious diseases.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: International aid: â€˜The money isnâ€™t coming back anytime soonâ€™, Fletcher warns
entry.summary: UN relief chief Tom Fletcher warned on Thursday that the global aid system must undergo a â€œhumanitarian resetâ€, becoming significantly more efficient and exploring new sources of funding, as major donors â€“ including the United States â€“ sharply reduce their contributions.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Israel must end â€˜cruel collective punishmentâ€™ in Gaza, urges UN relief chief
entry.summary: The UNâ€™s top humanitarian official on Thursday issued a stark warning over the continuing blockade of aid into Gaza, calling on Israel to lift restrictions that have left civilians without food, medical care, and hope.

entry.title: Jazz takes centre stage in Chicago for 2026
entry.summary: Chicago has been named host city for the 2026Â International Jazz Day festivities - coinciding with the 15th anniversary of the event and the 250th anniversary of the United States.

entry.title: This pig could save your life
entry.summary:
THE ENTRY REQUIREMENTS should have come with an instruction booklet: Sign in at the security hut. Shoes off at the door. Over to the locker room for a hot shower. Into a long protective surgical smock and knee-high rubber waders, and finally, a pair of safety goggles, whichâ€”in the clammy heat of the laboratory complexâ€”quickly began to fog.
â€œSorry for the trouble,â€ smiled my tour guide, BjÃ¶ern Petersen, waving me forward. â€œWe just have to be exceptionally careful about pathogens. Youâ€™ll get used to it, I promise.â€
A couple of hours earlier, Iâ€™d awoken in a hotel in a Midwestern city Iâ€™ve been asked not to name. Now, with the sun curdling above the surrounding pasture and a gauze of mist in the air, I found myself following Petersen, a German-born scientist, through the corridors oâ€¦

entry.title: Where to travel in June
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
June is the month of plenty. While some parts of the world are braced against hurricanes, monsoons and heat waves, the Northern Hemisphere is in its prime. The southern Med is ripe for striking out on a Croatian sailing tour or crisscrossing the Cyclades, while the Baltic and Nordic countries welcome bright nights and midsummer celebrations.
The dry season starts in safari spots across the globe like Uganda, Tanzania, Borneo and the Peruvian Amazon, making June an ideal time to view the Serengetiâ€™s Great Migration or orangutans swinging through Sabah rainforests.Â
The comfortable temperatures also afford opportunities for lovers of the great outdoors, including hiking the mountainous Inca Trail or trekking thrâ€¦

entry.title: These are the rules of king cobra fight club
entry.summary:
The braided motions of two cobra males twisting around each other is so hypnotic that if you didnâ€™t know better, you might think it was an intimate mating ritualâ€”and in a way it is.Â
The 12-foot-long males will wrap around each other for up to half an hour in a highly ritualized struggle to push their opponentâ€™s face into the dirt with an ignominious thud. Presumably, the snakes spar over access to females. The crazy thing isnâ€™t so much that they fight, but that these well-known snake eaters and occasional cannibals loaded with toxic venom donâ€™t choose the most violent path to victory. Instead, the serpents engage in a highly ritualized contest whose rules are implicitly understood by the combatants.
â€œKing cobras are venomousâ€”they could easily bite each other and kill each other â€¦

entry.title: Portable fans are the handy tools that deserve a place in your carry-on
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
During 2024â€™s record high temperatures, handheld portable fans surged in popularity. For travelers, these mini coolers can transcend trends to become a handy addition to a gear kit. But a quick online search reveals that choosing a portable fan isnâ€™t as simple as it may seem.Â
For one thing, the best personal fan isnâ€™t just easy to carry around. It should also be rechargeable, says Sunil Gupta, the co-founder and senior travel adviser at Luxury Indâ€¦

entry.title: This is the most scenic route through Acadia National Park
entry.summary:
Crushed stone crunches under feet, bike tires, and horse hooves on a late spring day inÂ Acadia National Park. Finally free of snow, the popular carriage roads are open, and visitors inhale the spruce-scented air deeply as they meander along the 8.6-mile Jordan Pond Loop. â€œMy first experience on the carriage roads was when I was growing up in Maine,â€ says MacKenzie Bowker, a guide forÂ Summer Feet Cycling & Walking. â€œI loved cycling with my dad on the roads because it was a quiet place to be and the chances to see wildlife were plentiful.â€
Iâ€™ve hiked hundreds of miles on national park trails in the United States, but have biked in far fewer parks because often the only option is to share crowded roads with vehicles. In Acadia, cyclists can enjoy the serenity of nature away from the noisâ€¦

entry.title: For a farm-to-table feast, visit Canadaâ€™s smallest province
entry.summary:
On a deserted beach on the far eastern coast of Canada's Prince Edward Island (also known as PEI), chef Nick Chindamo squats among a stand of low-growing weeds, their tips displaying the telltale yellowing of late summer. He rummages for a few seconds before holding out a fat, eight-leaved cluster of sea sandwort, an abundant coastal succulent in northern climates. â€œTry this,â€ he says. â€œIt will surprise you.â€
Heâ€™s right. The leaves, which resemble flattened versions of backyard-garden mainstays like ghost plant, are juicy, with a briny, cucumber-like flavor. Sandwort is among dozens of plants that Chindamo harvests during daily foraging adventures on various patches of scrub, sand, and forest that few would suspect of harboring a trove of edible plantsâ€”and that now make their way ontoâ€¦

entry.title: Could this be the end of menopause as we know it?
entry.summary:
"We don't have to accept menopause as destiny,â€ says Kutluk Oktay, an ovarian biologist and director of the Yale School of Medicine and Director of Laboratory of Molecular Reproduction and Fertility Preservation. Oktay, a leading researcher in fertility preservation, is one of the many scientists in the race to end menopause as we currently understand it.Â
For most women, menopause means a gradual decline of progesterone and estrogen beginning in their mid-40s. The menopausal transition, or perimenopause, can last between two and eight years, and even up to a decade, before menopause, the point at which a womanâ€™s menstrual period has stopped for a year. During perimenopause, women can experience a range of associated symptoms, including hot flashes to night sweats, pain during sex, joâ€¦

entry.title: Explore British Columbia with these wild experiences
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Itâ€™s impossible to resist the call of the wild in British Columbia. This Canadian province on the Pacific has a 17,000-mile coastline lined with mountainous fjords and studded with around 6,000 islands, most of which are uninhabited. Rainforest-fringed shores rise sharply to jagged peaks, home to Canadaâ€™s largest population of grizzlies. Take it all in with floatplane flightseeing, high-altitude hiking, remote kayaking and overnights at wilderness lodges built on Indigenous lands.
Hop aboard a Harbour Air floatplane and let the Pacific Ocean be your runway. Following a remote mail route of yesteryear, a classic De Havilland Canada DHC-2 Beaver will carry you low over BCâ€™s Gulf Islands â€” scattered between the â€¦

entry.summary: In Afghanistan, 75 per cent of the population struggles to meet their daily needs; with female-headed households, rural communities and internally displaced persons being most affected, the UN development agency (UNDP) has noted in a new report.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Haiti: Mass displacement and deportation surge amid violence
entry.summary: Marked by mass killings, abductions, and sexual violence, the first quarter of 2025, the human rights situation in Haiti remained extremely concerning, the UN deplored in a report published on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UNRWA warns against closure of six schools in East Jerusalem
entry.summary: The education of 800 students in occupied East Jerusalem is at risk as Israel moves to close their schools next week, a senior official with the UN agency for Palestine refugees, UNRWA, said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN alert over deepening crisis in Sudan as famine spreads and violence escalates
entry.summary: The United Nations has warned that Sudan is sliding deeper into catastrophe, with growing famine and surging violence â€“ particularly in North Darfur â€“ driving mass displacement and an alarming rise in civilian deaths.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: First Person: Myanmar aid workers brave conflict and harsh conditions to bring aid to earthquake victims
entry.summary: In the aftermath of the huge 7.7 magnitude earthquake that struck Myanmar on 28 March, life-saving aid efforts led by the UN are being hampered by damaged infrastructure, ongoing armed conflict and global aid funding cuts.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Syria: UN envoy warns of escalating violence in Syria
entry.summary: TheÂ UN Special Envoy for Syria, Geir Pedersen,Â voiced deep concern on Wednesday over the recent surge in violence across Syria, particularly in the suburbs of Damascus and in Homs.

entry.title: â€˜Recovery must move aheadâ€™ in southern Lebanon, top aid official says
entry.summary: The UN Humanitarian Coordinator for Lebanon has called for greater support to people in the south of the country working to rebuild their lives in the aftermath of last yearâ€™s hostilities between Israel and Hezbollah.

entry.title: Millions will die from funding cuts, says UN aid chief
entry.summary: Lifesaving operations everywhere continue to be shut down by sweeping funding cutbacks which will result in millions of people dying, the UNâ€™s top aid official said on Wednesday.

entry.title: These bats learn to eavesdropâ€”in order to survive
entry.summary:
During Panamaâ€™s wet season, forests boom with a chorus of tÃºngara frog mating calls as males compete for femalesâ€™ attention.But these calls put the frogs in a precarious position between sex and death. For a fringe-lipped bat, itâ€™s as though its meal is ringing a dinner bell.Â
Bats navigate the world with echolocation, listening to the sound waves of their own calls bouncing off nearby objects. Their hearing is so precise they can even home in on prey using ripples that frog calls make on water. undefinedA fringe-lipped bat, Trachops cirrhosus, responds to the calls of the tÃºngara frog, one of its preferred prey species. The bat hears the call of a single male tÃºngara frog, producing a complex call (a â€˜whineâ€™ plus multiple â€˜chucksâ€™). The bat then hears the cacophony of a large tÃºâ€¦

entry.title: Happiness isn't enoughâ€”here's why you should strive to 'flourish'
entry.summary:
What really makes for a fulfilling life? This question has been on Tyler J. VanderWeeleâ€™s mind for decades.
In his first faculty job as a biostatistician at the University of Chicago, he was dissatisfied with how scientists defined and measured human well-being. Â There were plenty of studies on specific measures of clinical symptoms, like depression, or emotional states like happiness or anxiety. Researchers had tracked objective markers of health, like blood pressure or sleep quality as well as were how economic conditions influence health.
But while these measures captured specific slices of both the problems and joys of life, VanderWeele felt they missed a holistic picture of what humans really seek, especially the need for meaning and purpose in life.
Since that first joâ€¦

entry.title: Tracking US Migrant Detention Data: What Journalists Need to Understand
entry.summary: The US government's detained immigrant population flatlined in April, but there's more to the numbers than meets the eye. Here's what journalists need to know about the data.

entry.title: The life of Lexington, Americaâ€™s greatest racehorse
entry.summary:
â€œBest Time ever Madeâ€ declared the headline in the Louisville Daily Courier on April 4, 1855. Two days earlier, at a racecourse in New Orleans, a champion thoroughbred named Lexington had run four miles in seven minutes, 19 and three-quarter seconds, smashing the previous record by more than six seconds.
Lexingtonâ€™s blazing speed record would stand unmatched for 20 years. But a severe infection had left the stallion blind in one eye and nearly so in the other. No longer able to race, he was sent to a stud farm, where he earned even greater renown.
â€œLexington sired a powerful lineage filled with champions today,â€ says Kim Wickens, author of a forthcoming book on the legendary racehorse. â€œHe was the most dominant horse of his day and passed those genes down to a phenomenal lineâ€¦

entry.title: 9 reasons to look up to the night sky this May
entry.summary:
Mayâ€™s night sky is filled with entertainment for stargazers, whether youâ€™re interested in observing planets, meteors, the moon, or even globular clusters. Grab your binoculars, set up your telescope, and get outsideâ€”hereâ€™s what to look for in the cosmos throughout the month.
Just after sunset, look to the west to spot a celestial â€œswarm.â€ The stars of the Beehive Cluster (Messier 44) will appear to buzz just below the crescent moon. Take a closer look, and you might notice one of the â€œbeesâ€ has a reddish hueâ€”thatâ€™s Mars joining the fun.
(Here are five famous constellations that (almost) anyone can find.)
The Beehive cluster, located about 577 light-years away, contains more than a thousand stars. While some can be seen with the naked eye, the clusterâ€™s dazzling display is â€¦

entry.title: Here are 4 archaeological trips you can take in 2025
The definitive list of running shoes for every kind of runner, according to pros
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
Running is often referred to as one of the most accessible forms of exerciseâ€”all you need is a good pair of shoes. But many runners will tell you not to skimp on those shoes. Your running shoes could be the key to your physical and mental breakthroughs. Or they could be the reason you spend the next week, months, or even years with an unshakeable injury.Â
Iâ€™ve been an avid runner since my high school cross country days in the late â€™90s. For a decadâ€¦

entry.title: Jet lag doesnâ€™t have to ruin your trip. Hereâ€™s what to do
entry.summary:
Hop a plane across several time zones, and you may end up with what scientists call circadian dysrhythmia (aka jet lag). Itâ€™s a temporary sleep disorder where your bodyâ€™s internal clock isnâ€™t in sync with the time cues in your destinationâ€”daylight, dark of night, mealtimes.
Itâ€™s also why you might doze off at lunch on your first day in London or be unable to get to sleep the first couple of nights of a vacation to Japan. â€œWe have a natural rhythm to our bodies, and itâ€™s pretty well set,â€ says Vivek Jain, director of the George Washington Universityâ€™s Center for Sleep Disorders.
But jet lag doesnâ€™t have to wreck your trip. â€œIf you plan for it, you can do most of your acclimatizing to your destination a few days in advance,â€ says W. Chris Winter, neurologist and author of The Sleepâ€¦

entry.title: Ho Chi Minh City is a food-lover's paradise. Here's where to eat
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Iâ€™m on the back of a Vespa, on my way to meet a gangster. Not that I know it yet. Night has descended and rain is slapping the tarmac with a fervent drumming. Weâ€™re soaked to the bone as we pull up outside a restaurant called Oc Loan on a small side street in Ho Chi Minh City. Water troughs are set out like street stalls, displaying snails bigger than my fist, plump clams and glistening river prawns. Presiding over them is a man in ripped denim shorts and flip-flops, weighed down by thick gold chains, knuckle dusters and gigantic cuffs. Needless to say, heâ€™s not the maÃ®tre dâ€™ Iâ€™d been expecting.
Inspired by Michelinâ€™s first restaurant guide to Ho Chi Minh, published in 2023, Iâ€™m taking a deep dive into the cityâ€™s eâ€¦

entry.title: Plague of rats and insects provide latest challenge for war-shattered Gazans
entry.summary: After suffering almost 18 months of deadly bombardment, displacement and lack of access to basic services, the embattled people of Gaza face yet another challenge: the threat of insects and rodents.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukraine: Ceasefire a critical first step on the road to durable peace
entry.summary: The UN political affairs chief underscored the urgent need for a ceasefire in Ukraine in a briefing to the Security Council on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Two-State solution nearing point of no return, warns UN chief
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General has warned that the two-State solution for Israel and Palestine is nearing collapse, urging world leaders to take bold, irreversible steps to preserve hopes for lasting peace.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Guterres on India-Pakistan tensions, eastern DR Congo update, weather boost for locusts in Africa
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres has expressed â€œdeep concernâ€ over rising tensions between India and Pakistan since the terror attack in Jammu and Kashmir a week ago in which 26 tourists were killed.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Stuck in the middle? Indebted nations plot path to growth amid global trade upheaval
entry.summary: Faced with mounting debt and economic stagnation, middle-income countries have issued a call for financial reform, sustainable investment, and a roadmap to escape the so-called â€œmiddle-income trap,â€ at a UN-backed international conference held in Manila, Philippines, which concluded on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Myanmar quake: Ongoing aftershocks spread fear
entry.summary: Aftershocks continue to sow fear across Myanmar, where millions remain inÂ desperate need of humanitarian aid a full month since a 7.7 magnitude earthquakeÂ killed more than 3,800 people and injured 5,100.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Hundreds of thousands of Afghans forced back into danger, says UNHCR
entry.summary: Afghanistanâ€™s escalating humanitarian crisis is being compounded by the mass return of its nationals from neighbouring countries, UN aid agencies warned on Tuesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: MIDDLE EAST LIVE: Guterres tells Security Council two-State solution â€˜near point of no returnâ€™
entry.summary: The Security Council has been meeting on the Middle East, with Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres telling ambassadors that irreversible action must be taken to finally put a two-State solution in place for Israel and Palestine. Meanwhile, the humanitarian crisis in Gaza deepens, with reports from the UN Palestine refugee relief agency (UNRWA) that children are "going to bed starving" amid the two-month Israeli aid blockade and continuing bombardment. App users can follow coverage here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Children in Gaza â€˜going to bed starvingâ€™ amid blockade
entry.summary: The biggest UN aid agency in Gaza on Tuesday condemned the two-month Israeli blockade that has left families eating barely enough to survive amid daily bombings â€“ and the sick and injured without lifesaving medical help.

entry.title: What the biggest flood on Earth looked like
entry.summary:
Six million years ago, the Mediterranean Sea wasnâ€™t nearly as picturesque as it is today. It was barely even a sea; tectonic activity had raised a mountain range in the Strait of Gibraltar, cutting off the Mediterranean from the Atlantic. Without a constant inflow of water the sea evaporated under the baking sun, and all that remained were a few scattered, briny lakes surrounded by mile after mile of salt and gypsum. Today, scientists call this the Messinian Salinity Crisis: in the dying days of the Miocene epoch, most of the Mediterranean died.Â
But if, on a certain day about 5.3 million years ago, you happened to go for a stroll along that mountain range, you might have discovered something odd: a trickle of water, making its way down one of the mountains from the Atlantic ocean beyâ€¦

entry.title: Australia has an absurdly huge feral camel problem
entry.summary:
Jack Carmody has builtÂ a sizable YouTube following by showing his viewers what it takes to run a cattle station in the Australian outbackâ€”the rugged work of mending troughs, reinforcing fences, and shooting trespassers. Feral horses and donkeys, that is, and one particularly destructive invasive species: camels. Introduced in the 19th century to help colonists survey the countryâ€™s vast interior, the creatures are now wreaking havoc across the outback and decimating the Carmody familyâ€™s ranch property, or what Australians call a cattle station. At more than 1,500 square miles, the propertyâ€”Prenti Downsâ€”is the size of Rhode Island, so thereâ€™s plenty of work to be done, and in this modern internet age, thereâ€™s plenty of content to be created.Â Â
On Carmodyâ€™s channel, Jack Out The Back, noâ€¦

entry.title: Why the Kentucky Derby is a 151-year-old celebration of hats
entry.summary:
Ladies show off their Derby hats before the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Kentucky. The Kentucky Derby is the longest continuously-held sporting event in American history. America's longest running sports event comes with a distinctive sartorial tradition.
Although horses may be the stars of the Kentucky Derby, hats take center stage at the 151-year old horse race in the American heartland.
In Kentucky, hatsâ€”the wilder the betterâ€”are central to the annual spring ritual, the â€œrun for the roses.â€ On the first Saturday of May, horse-racing fans gather at Churchill Downs to watch the â€œmost exciting two minutes in sports.â€
Big, bold, and steeped in tradition â€” here's everything you need to know about the history of hats at the Kentucky Dâ€¦

entry.title: Anxious about flying? These calming products may help.
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*Â
Travel can be exhilarating, but with so many moving parts and unpredictable factors, it can also be a major source of stress and anxiety. Navigating unfamiliar airports, managing time zone shifts, and adjusting to new surroundings take its toll. As a longtime travel writer, Iâ€™ve tested plenty of tools to help manage my nerves.Â Â
To find the best travel gear for anxiety, I spoke with seasoned travelers and mental health professionals for their advicâ€¦

entry.title: This Alpine spa town has been popular for centuriesâ€”here's why
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Morning light creeps over central Austriaâ€™s Hohe Tauern Alps, spotlighting summits one by one. As our yoga group launches into asanas, the valley below is bathed gold. There can be few lovelier spots to practise sun salutations than here, on a platform high in the forest of Bad Gastein, with a ringside seat of the mountains and within earshot of the townâ€™s waterfall. â€œItâ€™s a magical place,â€ says Annette SÃ¶hnlein, smiling as radiant as the new day.
Sheâ€™s leading a class at Haus Hirt, the Alpine-chic lodge where Iâ€™m staying for the week. Once a refuge for writers like Stefan Zweig and Thomas Mann, the 1920s building was redesigned in 2000, with contemporary art and rooms designed to frame the view. â€œHere in the embraâ€¦

entry.title: UN launches network to support victims and survivors of terrorism
entry.summary: A new UN initiative aims to drive collective action to support the rights and needs of people everywhere whose lives have been upended by the continuing threat posed terrorism.

entry.title: Gazans face hunger crisis as aid blockade nears two months
entry.summary: Surviving on one meal a day and stretching out rapidly dwindling food rations have become a desperate reality in the Gaza Strip, where humanitarian aid has been blocked for nearly two months.

entry.title: UN warns of $4 trillion shortfall threatening global development goals
entry.summary: Facing a staggering $4 trillion annual financing gap for development and mounting trade wars, top UN officials on Monday called for urgent action to rescue the Sustainable Development Goals and revive international cooperation.

entry.title: One in four female genital mutilation cases now carried out by health workers
entry.summary: Female genital mutilation (FGM) is becoming less common worldwide, but when it does occur, it is increasingly performed by professional healthcare workers, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) warned on Monday.

entry.summary: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) beganÂ hearings on Monday into Israelâ€™s continuing severe restrictions on the work of the UN and other international organizations in Gaza and the Occupied Palestinian Territories (OPT).

entry.title: How to plan the ultimate adventure along the Danube
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The Danube touches deep. Its landscapes are lyrical, its cities were built high and mighty by once-great empires, its history is as old as European civilisation itself. In 1866, Johann Strauss II extolled its beauty in The Blue Danube. And in 2025, on the 200th anniversary of the Austrian composerâ€™s birth, his ever-popular waltz still captures the sprightly soul of the river, which flows from the Black Forest in Germany to the Black Sea in Romania and Ukraine. Whether seen in the mist of winter or summerâ€™s first light, thereâ€™s poetry in these waters.
But where to begin? Many tours zoom in on the classic sights necklacing the Upper Danube between Germany and Hungary. The knockout is the 24-mile Wachau Valley in Uppeâ€¦

entry.title: There's a peaceful side to Bangkokâ€”if you know where to look
entry.summary:
Find peace within this energetic city by stepping in any of the Buddhist temples like Wat Arun. Thailandâ€™s capital city is a sensory overload, but between the tuk-tuk-packed streets and steamy markets thereâ€™s a serene, silent side to be found â€” and itâ€™s now easier to experience thanks to electric boat tours.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Captain Tai is the embodiment of Zen. He hops onto the deck of his royal-blue wooden boat, twiddles a few switches and we glide away from the canal bank in silence. Around us in the neighbourhoods that stem from the western banks of the Chao Phraya River, longtail boat owners race along the water, engines roaring, faces crumpled in scowls. But Captain Tai? Smiling.
Welcome to an entirely new version oâ€¦

entry.title: This Tuscan region is perfect for multi-generational vacations
entry.summary:
These naturally occurring hot springs were regarded as a gift from the gods by the Romans and Etruscans. Medieval hilltop towns, an unspoilt coastline and steamy hot springs make the Maremma region ideal for multi-generational holidays.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Southern Tuscany offers a quieter, more authentic escape to big-hitters such as Lucca and Siena, with a landscape defined by rolling vineyards, medieval hilltop towns and an unspoilt coastline. The Maremma region is an ideal base for multi-generational stays, and yet itâ€™s still easily accessible from Florence to the north and Rome to the south in about two hours by car. Whether you seek luxury, adventure or relaxation, this pocket of Southern Tuscany delivers an unforgettable exâ€¦

entry.title: Why the Faroe Islands should be your next road trip destination
entry.summary:
MÃºlafossur waterfall in GÃ¡sadalur is one of the Faroe Islandsâ€™ most famous natural wonders. Drive the Faroe Islandsâ€™ scenic byways to get lost amid the clouds, witness waterfalls blowing themselves inside out and find a sense of solitude certain to leave you craving more.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The weather is famously fickle in the Faroe Islands. In the mountains, roads vanish into fog within seconds; by the sea, winds howl with such force that coastal waterfalls are sent streaming skywards. Haircuts take on an unintentional punk-rock edge. But on the afternoon of my arrival, the skies are a rare, perfect blue. Everything shines.
Itâ€™s early spring and, through my windscreen, the northern light is giving the ocean an ever-variegaâ€¦

entry.title: Gaza: UN official warns of 'assault on dignity' as blockade cripples humanitarian response
entry.summary: The coming days in Gaza are set to be critical, the UN warned on Saturday, as humanitarian operations are severely curtailed amid an intensifying blockade, escalating violence, and soaring humanitarian needs.

entry.title: 7 ways to see the best of Greece's Peloponnese
entry.summary:
Myth has it that Voidokilia Beach is Homer's 'sandy Pylos', where Telemachus was welcomed by King Nestor when searching for Odysseus. A sleepy peninsula west of Athens, the Peloponnese offers uniquely Greek experiences ranging from visits to olive farms, boat trips into long-lost caves, rickety old train rides and mountain farm stays.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).Â
The southernmost part of mainland Greece is the image of the country that many travellers hold in their heads. Home to ancient sites that speak of myths and legends, and a coastline sprinkled with pretty villages and white-sand beaches, it has all the appeal of Greeceâ€™s islands but few of their crowds. But there are plenty of other reasons to plan a trip, too, from staying on an â€¦
